         <td><a href="/wiki/.uk" title=".uk">.uk</a><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[nb 5]</a></sup></td>
       </tr></table>
<p>The <b>United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland</b>,<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[nb 6]</a></sup> commonly known as the <b>United Kingdom</b> (<b>UK</b>) or <b>Britain</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>), is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sovereign_state&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sovereign state (page does not exist)">sovereign state</a> located off the north-western coast of <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">continental Europe</a>. The country includes the island of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Britain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Britain (page does not exist)">Great Britain</a> (a term sometimes loosely applied to the whole state), the north-eastern part of the island of <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a>, and many smaller islands. <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> is the only part of the UK that shares a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_Ireland_%E2%80%93_United_Kingdom_border&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republic of Ireland – United Kingdom border (page does not exist)">land border</a> with another state: the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Republic of Ireland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[nb 7]</a></sup> Apart from this land border, the UK is surrounded by the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> in the east, the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a> in the south and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Irish_Sea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irish Sea (page does not exist)">Irish Sea</a> in the west.
</p><p>The UK's form of government is a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[11]</a></sup> with a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a> and its <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">capital city</a> is <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>. The current <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">British monarch</a>—since 6 February 1952—is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth II (page does not exist)">Queen Elizabeth II</a>. The United Kingdom consists of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Countries of the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">four countries</a>: <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-page823_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-page823-19">[12]</a></sup> The latter three have <a href="/w/index.php?title=Devolution_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Devolution in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">devolved</a> administrations,<sup id="cite_ref-devoladmins_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-devoladmins-20">[13]</a></sup> each with varying powers,<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[15]</a></sup> based in their capital cities, <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a> and <a href="/wiki/Belfast" title="Belfast">Belfast</a>, respectively. <a href="/wiki/Guernsey" title="Guernsey">Guernsey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jersey" title="Jersey">Jersey</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">Isle of Man</a> are <a href="/wiki/Crown_dependencies" title="Crown dependencies">Crown dependencies</a> and are not part of the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[16]</a></sup> The United Kingdom has fourteen <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">British Overseas Territories</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[17]</a></sup> These are remnants of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> which, at its height in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, encompassed almost a quarter of the world's land mass and was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_largest_empires&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of largest empires (page does not exist)">largest empire in history</a>. British influence can be observed in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English language (page does not exist)">language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">legal systems</a> of many of its former colonies.
</p><p>The United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a> and has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">sixth-largest economy</a> by nominal GDP and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">eighth-largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a>. It was the world's first <a href="/wiki/Industrialisation" title="Industrialisation">industrialised</a> country<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[18]</a></sup> and the world's <a href="/wiki/Power_(international_relations)" title="Power (international relations)">foremost power</a> during the 19th and early 20th centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-ferguson_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ferguson-26">[19]</a></sup> The UK remains a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a> with considerable economic, cultural, military, scientific and political influence internationally.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[21]</a></sup> It is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_Non-Proliferation_Treaty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (page does not exist)">recognised</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear weapons state</a> and its <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by military expenditures (page does not exist)">military expenditure ranks fourth</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK has been a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council (page does not exist)">permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> since its first session in 1946. It has been a member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Member_state_of_the_European_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Member state of the European Union (page does not exist)">European Union</a> (EU) and its predecessor the European Economic Community (EEC) since 1973; it is also a member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Commonwealth of Nations (page does not exist)">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G8" title="G8">G8</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (page does not exist)">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD) and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO).
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology_and_terminology">Etymology and terminology</span></h2>
<p>{{#invoke:anchor|main}}<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The 1707 <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707" title="Acts of Union 1707">Acts of Union</a> declared that the Kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">England</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kingdom_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kingdom of Scotland (page does not exist)">Scotland</a> were "United into One Kingdom by the Name of Great Britain" though the new state is also referred to in the Acts as the <i>United Kingdom of Great Britain</i> and the <i>United Kingdom</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[nb 8]</a></sup> The term <i>United Kingdom</i> is found in informal use during the 18th century and the country was occasionally referred to as the "United Kingdom of Great Britain".<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[25]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800" title="Acts of Union 1800">Acts of Union 1800</a> united the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">Kingdom of Great Britain</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland" title="Kingdom of Ireland">Kingdom of Ireland</a> in 1801, and created the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland</a>. The name "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland" was adopted by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_and_Parliamentary_Titles_Act_1927" title="Royal and Parliamentary Titles Act 1927">Royal and Parliamentary Titles Act 1927</a>. It reflected the independence of the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">Irish Free State</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Partition_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Partition of Ireland (page does not exist)">partition of Ireland</a>, in 1922, which left Northern Ireland as the only part of the island of Ireland within the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the United Kingdom, as a sovereign state, is a country, England, Scotland, Wales and (more controversially) Northern Ireland are also regarded as 'countries', though not sovereign states. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have devolved self-government.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-citizenship_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citizenship-36">[28]</a></sup> The British Prime Minister's website has used the phrase "countries within a country" to describe the United Kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-page823_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-page823-19">[12]</a></sup> With regard to Northern Ireland, the descriptive name used "can be controversial, with the choice often revealing one's political preferences."<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[29]</a></sup> Terms used for Northern Ireland include "region" and "province".<sup id="cite_ref-alphabeticalNI_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alphabeticalNI-38">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-placeApart_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-placeApart-39">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>The term <i>Britain</i> is often used as synonym for the United Kingdom. The term <i>Great Britain</i>, by contrast, refers geographically to the island of Great Britain, or politically to England, Scotland and Wales in combination.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[34]</a></sup>  However, it is sometimes used as a loose synonym for the United Kingdom as a whole.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[36]</a></sup> <i>GB</i> and <i>GBR</i> are the <a href="/wiki/International_Organization_for_Standardization" title="International Organization for Standardization">standard</a> country codes for the United Kingdom (see <a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:GB" title="ISO 3166-2:GB">ISO 3166-2</a> and <a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-3" title="ISO 3166-1 alpha-3">ISO 3166-1 alpha-3</a>) and are consequently used by international organisations to refer to the United Kingdom. Also, the United Kingdom's Olympic team competes under the name "Great Britain" or "Team GB".<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Team_GB_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Team_GB-46">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>The adjective <i>British</i> is commonly used to refer to matters relating to the United Kingdom. The term has no definite legal connotation, however, it is used in law to refer to UK citizenship and <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_nationality_law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British nationality law (page does not exist)">matters to do with nationality</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bradley_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bradley-47">[39]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British people (page does not exist)">British people</a> use a number of different terms to describe their national identity and may identify themselves as being British; or as being English, Scottish, Welsh, Northern Irish, or Irish;<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[40]</a></sup> or as being both.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2006, a new design of <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_passport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British passport (page does not exist)">British passport</a> was introduced. Its first page shows the long form name of the state in English, <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">Scottish Gaelic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[42]</a></sup> In Welsh, the long form name of the state is "Teyrnas Unedig Prydain Fawr a Gogledd Iwerddon" with "Teyrnas Unedig" being used as a short form name on government websites.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[43]</a></sup> In Scottish Gaelic, the long form is "Rìoghachd Aonaichte na Breatainne Mòire is Èireann a Tuath" and the short form "Rìoghachd Aonaichte".
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Before_1707">Before 1707</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Stonehenge2007_07_30.jpg" title="File:Stonehenge2007 07 30.jpg">File:Stonehenge2007 07 30.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Stonehenge" title="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Wiltshire" title="Wiltshire">Wiltshire</a>, was erected around 2500 BC.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Settlement by <a href="/wiki/Cro-Magnons" title="Cro-Magnons" class="mw-redirect">anatomically modern humans</a> of what was to become the United Kingdom occurred <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prehistoric_settlement_of_the_British_Isles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prehistoric settlement of the British Isles (page does not exist)">in waves beginning by about 30,000 years ago</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[44]</a></sup> By the end of the <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Britain" title="Prehistoric Britain">region's prehistoric period</a>, the population is thought to have belonged, in the main, to a culture termed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Insular_Celts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Insular Celts (page does not exist)">Insular Celtic</a>, comprising <a href="/w/index.php?title=Britons_(historical)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Britons (historical) (page does not exist)">Brythonic Britain</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gaelic_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gaelic Ireland (page does not exist)">Gaelic Ireland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[45]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Roman_conquest_of_Britain" title="Roman conquest of Britain">Roman conquest</a>, beginning in 43 AD, and the 400-year <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">rule of southern Britain</a>, was followed by an invasion by <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anglo-Saxon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anglo-Saxon (page does not exist)">Anglo-Saxon</a> settlers, reducing the Brythonic area <a href="/wiki/Wales#Medieval_Wales" title="Wales">mainly to what was to become Wales</a> and the historic <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Strathclyde" title="Kingdom of Strathclyde">Kingdom of Strathclyde</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[46]</a></sup> Most of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anglo-Saxon_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anglo-Saxon England (page does not exist)">region settled by the Anglo-Saxons</a> became unified as the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">Kingdom of England</a> in the 10th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Short_Athelstan_biography_on_the_BBC_History_website_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Short_Athelstan_biography_on_the_BBC_History_website-55">[47]</a></sup> Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/D%C3%A1l_Riata" title="Dál Riata">Gaelic-speakers in north west Britain</a> (with connections to the north-east of Ireland and traditionally supposed to have migrated from there in the 5th century)<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[49]</a></sup> united with the <a href="/wiki/Picts" title="Picts">Picts</a> to create the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kingdom_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kingdom of Scotland (page does not exist)">Kingdom of Scotland</a> in the 9th century.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1066, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Normans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Normans (page does not exist)">Normans</a> invaded England from France and after <a href="/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England" title="Norman conquest of England">its conquest</a>, seized <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norman_invasion_of_Wales&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norman invasion of Wales (page does not exist)">large parts of Wales</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norman_invasion_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norman invasion of Ireland (page does not exist)">conquered much of Ireland</a> and were invited to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Davidian_Revolution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Davidian Revolution (page does not exist)">settle in Scotland</a>, bringing to each country <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a> on the Northern French model and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norman-French&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norman-French (page does not exist)">Norman-French</a> culture.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[51]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Norman" title="Anglo-Norman">Norman elites</a> greatly influenced, but eventually assimilated with, each of the local cultures.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[52]</a></sup> Subsequent <a href="/wiki/House_of_Plantagenet" title="House of Plantagenet">medieval English kings</a> completed the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Conquest_of_Wales&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Conquest of Wales (page does not exist)">conquest of Wales</a> and made an unsuccessful <a href="/wiki/Wars_of_Scottish_Independence" title="Wars of Scottish Independence">attempt to annex Scotland</a>. Thereafter, Scotland maintained its independence, albeit in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anglo-Scottish_Wars&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anglo-Scottish Wars (page does not exist)">near-constant conflict with England</a>. The English monarchs, through inheritance of <a href="/wiki/Angevin_Empire" title="Angevin Empire">substantial territories in France</a> and claims to the French crown, were also heavily involved in conflicts in France, most notably the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hundred_Years_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hundred Years War (page does not exist)">Hundred Years War</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Scottish_monarchs" title="List of Scottish monarchs">Kings of Scots</a> were in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Auld_Alliance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Auld Alliance (page does not exist)">an alliance with the French</a> during this period.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg" title="File:Bayeux Tapestry WillelmDux.jpg">File:Bayeux Tapestry WillelmDux.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Bayeux_Tapestry" title="Bayeux Tapestry">Bayeux Tapestry</a> depicts the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hastings" title="Battle of Hastings">Battle of Hastings</a> and the events leading to it.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Early_Modern_Britain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Early Modern Britain (page does not exist)">early modern period</a> saw religious conflict resulting from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reformation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reformation (page does not exist)">Reformation</a> and the introduction of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protestantism_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protestantism in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Protestant</a> state churches in each country.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[54]</a></sup> Wales was <a href="/wiki/Laws_in_Wales_Acts_1535%E2%80%931542" title="Laws in Wales Acts 1535–1542">fully incorporated into the Kingdom of England</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Tudors_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Tudors-63">[55]</a></sup> and Ireland was constituted as a kingdom in personal union with the English crown.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[56]</a></sup> In what was to become Northern Ireland, the lands of the independent Catholic Gaelic nobility were confiscated and <a href="/wiki/Plantation_of_Ulster" title="Plantation of Ulster">given to Protestant settlers</a> from England and Scotland.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1603, the kingdoms of England, Scotland and Ireland were united in a <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">personal union</a> when <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_I_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James I of England (page does not exist)">James VI, King of Scots</a>, inherited the crowns of England and Ireland and moved his court from Edinburgh to London; each country nevertheless remained a separate political entity and retained its separate political, legal, and religious institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-D._Ross.2C_2002_p._56_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-D._Ross.2C_2002_p._56-66">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-J._Hearn.2C_2002_p._104_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-J._Hearn.2C_2002_p._104-67">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the mid-17th century, all three kingdoms <a href="/wiki/Wars_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Wars of the Three Kingdoms">were involved in a series of connected wars</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/English_Civil_War" title="English Civil War">English Civil War</a>) which led to the temporary overthrow of the monarchy and the establishment of the short-lived <a href="/w/index.php?title=Unitary_republic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unitary republic (page does not exist)">unitary republic</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_England" title="Commonwealth of England">Commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the monarchy was restored, it ensured (with the <a href="/wiki/Glorious_Revolution" title="Glorious Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a> of 1688) that, unlike much of the rest of Europe, <a href="/wiki/Royal_absolutism" title="Royal absolutism" class="mw-redirect">royal absolutism</a> would not prevail, and a professed Catholic could never accede to the throne. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_constitution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British constitution (page does not exist)">British constitution</a> would develop on the basis of <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[62]</a></sup> During this period, particularly in England, the development of <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_navy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English navy (page does not exist)">naval power</a> (and the interest in <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">voyages of discovery</a>) led to the acquisition and settlement of <a href="/w/index.php?title=First_British_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="First British Empire (page does not exist)">overseas colonies</a>, particularly in North America.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Since_the_Acts_of_Union_of_1707">Since the Acts of Union of 1707</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Union.jpg" title="File:Treaty of Union.jpg">File:Treaty of Union.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treaty of Union (page does not exist)">Treaty of Union</a> led to a single united kingdom encompassing all Great Britain.</div></div></div>
<p>On 1 May 1707, the united <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">kingdom of Great Britain</a> came into being, the result of <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707" title="Acts of Union 1707">Acts of Union</a> being passed by the parliaments of England and Scotland to ratify the 1706 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treaty of Union (page does not exist)">Treaty of Union</a> and so unite the two kingdoms.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 18th century, cabinet government developed under <a href="/wiki/Robert_Walpole" title="Robert Walpole">Robert Walpole</a>, in practice the first prime minister (1721–1742). A series of <a href="/wiki/Jacobite_Uprisings" title="Jacobite Uprisings" class="mw-redirect">Jacobite Uprisings</a> sought to remove the Protestant <a href="/wiki/House_of_Hanover" title="House of Hanover">House of Hanover</a> from the British throne and restore the Catholic <a href="/wiki/House_of_Stuart" title="House of Stuart">House of Stuart</a>. The Jacobites were finally defeated at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Culloden" title="Battle of Culloden">Battle of Culloden</a> in 1746, after which the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlanders" title="Scottish Highlanders" class="mw-redirect">Scottish Highlanders</a> were brutally suppressed. The British colonies in North America that broke away from Britain in the <a href="/wiki/American_War_of_Independence" title="American War of Independence" class="mw-redirect">American War of Independence</a> became the United States of America in 1782. British imperial ambition turned elsewhere, particularly to <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 18th century, Britain was involved in the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">Atlantic slave trade</a>. Britain transported an estimated 2 million slaves from Africa to the West Indies before banning the trade in 1807.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[69]</a></sup> The term 'United Kingdom' became official in 1801 when the parliaments of Britain and Ireland each passed an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Acts_of_Union_(1800)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Acts of Union (1800) (page does not exist)">Act of Union</a>, uniting the two kingdoms and creating the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early 19th century, the British-led <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> began to transform the country. It slowly led to a shift in political power away from the old <a href="/wiki/Tory" title="Tory">Tory</a> and <a href="/wiki/Whiggism" title="Whiggism">Whig</a> landowning classes towards the new industrialists. An alliance of merchants and industrialists with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Whig_(British_political_party)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Whig (British political party) (page does not exist)">Whigs</a> would lead to a new party, the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_(UK)" title="Liberal Party (UK)">Liberals</a>, with an ideology of <a href="/wiki/Free_trade" title="Free trade">free trade</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Laissez-faire" title="Laissez-faire">laissez-faire</a></i>. In 1832 Parliament passed the <a href="/wiki/Great_Reform_Act" title="Great Reform Act" class="mw-redirect">Great Reform Act</a>, which began the transfer of political power from the aristocracy to the middle classes. In the countryside, <a href="/wiki/Enclosure" title="Enclosure">enclosure</a> of the land was driving small farmers out. Towns and cities began to swell with a new urban working class. Few ordinary workers had the vote, and they created their own organisations in the form of <a href="/wiki/Trade_unions" title="Trade unions" class="mw-redirect">trade unions</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG" title="File:Battle of Waterloo 1815.PNG">File:Battle of Waterloo 1815.PNG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Waterloo" title="Battle of Waterloo">Battle of Waterloo</a> marked the end of the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> and the start of <a href="/wiki/Pax_Britannica" title="Pax Britannica">Pax Britannica</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>After the defeat of France in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=French_revolutionary_wars&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="French revolutionary wars (page does not exist)">Revolutionary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> (1792–1815), the UK emerged as the principal naval and imperial power of the 19th century (with London the largest city in the world from about 1830).<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[71]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy#1815.E2.80.931914" title="Royal Navy">Unchallenged at sea</a>, British dominance was later described as <i><a href="/wiki/Pax_Britannica" title="Pax Britannica">Pax Britannica</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[72]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[73]</a></sup> By the time of <a href="/wiki/The_Great_Exhibition" title="The Great Exhibition">the Great Exhibition</a> of 1851, Britain was described as the "workshop of the world".<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[74]</a></sup> The British Empire was expanded to include <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Raj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Raj (page does not exist)">India</a>, large <a href="/wiki/British_Empire#Cape_to_Cairo" title="British Empire">parts of Africa</a> and many other territories throughout the world. Alongside the formal control it exerted over its own colonies, British dominance of much of world trade meant that it effectively controlled the economies of many countries, such as China, Argentina and <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Siam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[76]</a></sup> Domestically, political attitudes favoured free trade and laissez-faire policies and a gradual widening of the voting franchise. During the century, the population increased at a dramatic rate, accompanied by rapid urbanisation, causing significant social and economic stresses.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[77]</a></sup> After 1875, the UK's industrial monopoly was challenged by Germany and the USA. To seek new markets and sources of raw materials, the <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">Conservative Party</a> under <a href="/wiki/Disraeli" title="Disraeli" class="mw-redirect">Disraeli</a> launched a period of imperialist expansion in Egypt, South Africa and elsewhere. Canada, Australia and New Zealand became self-governing dominions.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>Social reform and home rule for Ireland were important domestic issues after 1900. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Labour_Party_(UK)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Labour Party (UK) (page does not exist)">Labour Party</a> emerged from an alliance of trade unions and small Socialist groups in 1900, and <a href="/wiki/Suffragettes" title="Suffragettes" class="mw-redirect">suffragettes</a> campaigned for women's right to vote before 1914.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg" title="File:Royal Irish Rifles ration party Somme July 1916.jpg">File:Royal Irish Rifles ration party Somme July 1916.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Infantry of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Ulster_Rifles" title="Royal Ulster Rifles">Royal Irish Rifles</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Battle of the Somme</a>. More than 885,000 British soldiers died on the battlefields of World War I.</div></div></div>
<p>The UK fought with France, Russia and (after 1917) the US, against Germany and its allies in the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War" class="mw-redirect">First World War</a> (1914–18).<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[79]</a></sup> The UK armed forces were engaged across much of the British Empire and in several regions of Europe, particularly on the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western front</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Westwell.26Cove_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Westwell.26Cove-88">[80]</a></sup> The high fatalities of trench warfare caused the loss of much of a generation of men, with lasting social effects in the nation and a great disruption in the social order.
</p><p>After the war, the UK received the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> mandate over a number of former German and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> colonies. The British Empire reached its greatest extent, covering a fifth of the world's land surface and a quarter of its population.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[81]</a></sup> However, the UK had suffered 2.5 million casualties and finished the war with a huge national debt.<sup id="cite_ref-Westwell.26Cove_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Westwell.26Cove-88">[80]</a></sup> The rise of <a href="/wiki/Irish_Nationalism" title="Irish Nationalism" class="mw-redirect">Irish Nationalism</a> and disputes within Ireland over the terms of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Irish_Home_Rule&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irish Home Rule (page does not exist)">Irish Home Rule</a> led eventually to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Partition_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Partition of Ireland (page does not exist)">partition of the island</a> in 1921,<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[82]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">Irish Free State</a> became independent with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominion (page does not exist)">Dominion status</a> in 1922. Northern Ireland remained part of the United Kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-CAIN_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CAIN-91">[83]</a></sup> A wave of strikes in the mid-1920s culminated in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UK_General_Strike_of_1926&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UK General Strike of 1926 (page does not exist)">UK General Strike of 1926</a>. The UK had still not recovered from the effects of the war when the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Great Depression in the United Kingdom">Great Depression</a> (1929–32) occurred. This led to considerable unemployment and hardship in the old industrial areas, as well as political and social unrest in the 1930s. A coalition government was formed in 1931.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK entered World War II by declaring war on Germany in 1939, after it had invaded Poland and Czechoslovakia. In 1940, Winston Churchill became prime minister and head of a coalition government. Despite the defeat of its European allies in the first year of the war, the UK continued the fight alone against Germany. In 1940, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=RAF&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RAF (page does not exist)">RAF</a> defeated the German <a href="/wiki/Luftwaffe" title="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a> in a struggle for control of the skies in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Britain" title="Battle of Britain">Battle of Britain</a>. The UK suffered heavy bombing during <a href="/wiki/The_Blitz" title="The Blitz">the Blitz</a>. There were also eventual hard-fought victories in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_the_Atlantic_(1939%E2%80%931945)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battle of the Atlantic (1939–1945) (page does not exist)">Battle of the Atlantic</a>, the <a href="/wiki/North_Africa_campaign" title="North Africa campaign" class="mw-redirect">North Africa campaign</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Burma_campaign&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Burma campaign (page does not exist)">Burma campaign</a>. UK forces played an important role in the <a href="/wiki/Normandy_landings" title="Normandy landings">Normandy landings</a> of 1944, achieved with its ally the US. After Germany's defeat, the UK was one of the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Big Three</a> powers who met to plan the post-war world; it was an original signatory to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Declaration_of_the_United_Nations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Declaration of the United Nations (page does not exist)">Declaration of the United Nations</a>. The UK became one of the five permanent members of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>. However, the war left the UK severely weakened and depending financially on <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Aid</a> and loans from the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[85]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_British_Empire.png" title="File:The British Empire.png">File:The British Empire.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Territories that were at one time part of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>. Current <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">British Overseas Territories</a> are underlined in red.</div></div></div>
<p>In the immediate post-war years, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Labour_Government_1945%E2%80%931951&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Labour Government 1945–1951 (page does not exist)">Labour government</a> initiated a radical programme of reforms, which had a significant effect on British society in the following decades.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[86]</a></sup> Major industries and public utilities were <a href="/wiki/Nationalised" title="Nationalised" class="mw-redirect">nationalised</a>, a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Welfare_State&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Welfare State (page does not exist)">Welfare State</a> was established, and a comprehensive, publicly funded healthcare system, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Health_Service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Health Service (page does not exist)">National Health Service</a>, was created.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[87]</a></sup> The rise of nationalism in the colonies coincided with Britain's now much-diminished economic position, so that a policy of <a href="/wiki/Decolonisation" title="Decolonisation" class="mw-redirect">decolonisation</a> was unavoidable. Independence was granted to <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> in 1947.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[88]</a></sup> Over the next three decades, most colonies of the British Empire gained their independence. Many became members of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Commonwealth of Nations (page does not exist)">Commonwealth of Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the UK was the third country to develop <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_the_United_Kingdom" title="Nuclear weapons and the United Kingdom">a nuclear weapons arsenal</a> (with its <a href="/wiki/Operation_Hurricane" title="Operation Hurricane">first atomic bomb test</a> in 1952), the new post-war limits of Britain's international role were illustrated by the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Suez Crisis</a> of 1956. The international spread of the English language ensured the continuing international influence of its <a href="/wiki/British_literature" title="British literature">literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">culture</a>. From the 1960s onward, its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Popular_culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Popular culture (page does not exist)">popular</a>  culture was also influential abroad. As a result of a shortage of workers in the 1950s, the UK government encouraged immigration from Commonwealth countries. In the following decades, the UK became a multi-ethnic society.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[90]</a></sup> Despite rising living standards in the late 1950s and 1960s, the UK's economic performance was not as successful as many of its competitors, such as West Germany and Japan. In 1973, the UK joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC), and when the EEC became the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU) in 1992, it was one of the 12 founding members.
</p><p>From the late 1960s, Northern Ireland suffered communal and paramilitary violence (sometimes affecting other parts of the UK) conventionally known as <a href="/wiki/The_Troubles" title="The Troubles">the Troubles</a>. It is usually considered to have ended with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Belfast_Agreement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Belfast Agreement (page does not exist)">Belfast "Good Friday" Agreement</a> of 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[91]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hope_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hope-100">[92]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following a period of widespread economic slowdown and industrial strife in the 1970s, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Conservative_Government_1979%E2%80%931990&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Conservative Government 1979–1990 (page does not exist)">Conservative Government of the 1980s</a> initiated a radical policy of <a href="/wiki/Monetarism" title="Monetarism">monetarism</a>, deregulation, particularly of the financial sector (for example, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Big_Bang_(financial_markets)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Big Bang (financial markets) (page does not exist)">Big Bang</a> in 1986) and labour markets, the sale of state-owned companies (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Privatisation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Privatisation (page does not exist)">privatisation</a>), and the withdrawal of subsidies to others.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[94]</a></sup> This resulted in high unemployment and social unrest, but ultimately also economic growth, particularly in the services sector. From 1984, the economy was helped by the inflow of substantial <a href="/wiki/North_Sea_oil" title="North Sea oil">North Sea oil</a> revenues.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around the end of the 20th century there were major changes to the governance of the UK with the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved</a> administrations<sup id="cite_ref-devoladmins_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-devoladmins-20">[13]</a></sup> for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[96]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Act_1998" title="Human Rights Act 1998">statutory incorporation</a> followed acceptance of the <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">European Convention on Human Rights</a>. The UK is still a key global player diplomatically and militarily. It plays leading roles in the EU, UN and NATO. However, controversy surrounds some of Britain's overseas <a href="/w/index.php?title=Military_deployment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Military deployment (page does not exist)">military deployments</a>, particularly in <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–present) (page does not exist)">Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq" title="2003 invasion of Iraq">Iraq</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, the UK is striving to recover from a slump that followed the 2008 global financial crisis. A coalition government has introduced austerity measures which aim to tackle a large budget deficit.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[98]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_Independence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish Independence (page does not exist)">Scottish Independence</a> is back on the agenda. The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a> will hold an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_independence_referendum,_2014&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish independence referendum, 2014 (page does not exist)">independence referendum</a> on 18 September 2014. If passed Scotland will become a sovereign state independent of the other nations within the current UK.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-107">[99]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Uk_topo_en.jpg" title="File:Uk topo en.jpg">File:Uk topo en.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The topography of the UK</div></div></div>
<p>The total area of the United Kingdom is approximately <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The country occupies the major part of the <a href="/wiki/British_Isles" title="British Isles">British Isles</a><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[100]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> and includes the island of Great Britain, the north-eastern one-sixth of the island of Ireland and some smaller surrounding islands. It lies between the North Atlantic Ocean and the North Sea with the south-east coast coming within <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of the coast of northern France, from which it is separated by the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-factbook_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-109">[101]</a></sup> In 1993 10% of the UK was forested, 46% used for pastures and 25% cultivated for agriculture.<sup id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-110">[102]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich" title="Royal Observatory, Greenwich">Royal Greenwich Observatory</a> in London is the defining point of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Meridian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prime Meridian (page does not exist)">Prime Meridian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p>The United Kingdom lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/49th_parallel_north" title="49th parallel north">49°</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=61st_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="61st parallel north (page does not exist)">61° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/w/index.php?title=9th_meridian_west&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="9th meridian west (page does not exist)">9° W</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=2nd_meridian_east&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2nd meridian east (page does not exist)">2° E</a>. Northern Ireland shares a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> land boundary with the Republic of Ireland.<sup id="cite_ref-factbook_109-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-109">[101]</a></sup> The coastline of Great Britain is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> long.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[104]</a></sup> It is connected to <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">continental Europe</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Tunnel" title="Channel Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a>, which at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> underwater) is the longest underwater tunnel in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_England" title="Geography of England">England</a> accounts for just over half of the total area of the UK, covering <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[106]</a></sup> Most of the country consists of lowland terrain,<sup id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_110-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-110">[102]</a></sup> with mountainous terrain north-west of the <a href="/wiki/Tees-Exe_line" title="Tees-Exe line">Tees-Exe line</a>; including the <a href="/wiki/Lake_District" title="Lake District">Cumbrian Mountains</a> of the Lake District, the <a href="/wiki/Pennines" title="Pennines">Pennines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a> hills of the <a href="/wiki/Peak_District" title="Peak District">Peak District</a>, <a href="/wiki/Exmoor" title="Exmoor">Exmoor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dartmoor" title="Dartmoor">Dartmoor</a>. The main rivers and estuaries are the <a href="/wiki/River_Thames" title="River Thames">Thames</a>, <a href="/wiki/River_Severn" title="River Severn">Severn</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Humber" title="Humber">Humber</a>. England's highest mountain is <a href="/wiki/Scafell_Pike" title="Scafell Pike">Scafell Pike</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>) in the <a href="/wiki/Lake_District" title="Lake District">Lake District</a>. Its principal <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rivers_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rivers of England (page does not exist)">rivers</a> are the Severn, Thames, Humber, Tees, Tyne, Tweed, Avon, Exe and Mersey.<sup id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_110-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-110">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Geography of Scotland (page does not exist)">Scotland</a> accounts for just under a third of the total area of the UK, covering <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[107]</a></sup> and including nearly eight hundred <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Scotland" title="List of islands of Scotland">islands</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[108]</a></sup> predominantly west and north of the mainland; notably the <a href="/wiki/Hebrides" title="Hebrides">Hebrides</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orkney" title="Orkney">Orkney Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shetland" title="Shetland">Shetland Islands</a>. The topography of Scotland is distinguished by the <a href="/wiki/Highland_Boundary_Fault" title="Highland Boundary Fault">Highland Boundary Fault</a> – a <a href="/wiki/Fault_(geology)" title="Fault (geology)">geological rock fracture</a> – which traverses Scotland from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isle_of_Arran&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isle of Arran (page does not exist)">Arran</a> in the west to <a href="/wiki/Stonehaven" title="Stonehaven">Stonehaven</a> in the east.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[109]</a></sup> The faultline separates two distinctively different regions; namely the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">Highlands</a> to the north and west and the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Lowlands" title="Scottish Lowlands">lowlands</a> to the south and east. The more rugged Highland region contains the majority of Scotland's mountainous land, including <a href="/wiki/Ben_Nevis" title="Ben Nevis">Ben Nevis</a> which at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> is the highest point in the British Isles.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[110]</a></sup> Lowland areas – especially the narrow waist of land between the <a href="/wiki/Firth_of_Clyde" title="Firth of Clyde">Firth of Clyde</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Firth_of_Forth" title="Firth of Forth">Firth of Forth</a> known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Lowlands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Lowlands (page does not exist)">Central Belt</a> – are flatter and home to most of the population including <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, Scotland's largest city, and <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>, its capital and political centre.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BenNevis2005.jpg" title="File:BenNevis2005.jpg">File:BenNevis2005.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Ben_Nevis" title="Ben Nevis">Ben Nevis</a>, in Scotland, is the highest point in the <a href="/wiki/British_Isles" title="British Isles">British Isles</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Wales" title="Geography of Wales">Wales</a> accounts for less than a tenth of the total area of the UK, covering <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[111]</a></sup> Wales is mostly mountainous, though <a href="/wiki/South_Wales" title="South Wales">South Wales</a> is less mountainous than <a href="/wiki/North_Wales" title="North Wales">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mid_Wales" title="Mid Wales">mid Wales</a>. The main population and industrial areas are in South Wales, consisting of the coastal cities of Cardiff, Swansea and Newport, and the <a href="/wiki/South_Wales_Valleys" title="South Wales Valleys">South Wales Valleys</a> to their north. The highest mountains in Wales are in <a href="/wiki/Snowdonia" title="Snowdonia">Snowdonia</a> and include <a href="/wiki/Snowdon" title="Snowdon">Snowdon</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-cy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-cy (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-cy</a>) which, at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, is the highest peak in Wales.<sup id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_110-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-110">[102]</a></sup> The 14, or possibly 15, Welsh mountains over 3,000&#160;feet (914&#160;m) high are known collectively as the <a href="/wiki/Welsh_3000s" title="Welsh 3000s">Welsh 3000s</a>. Wales has over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of coastline. There are several islands off the Welsh mainland, the largest of which is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anglesey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anglesey (page does not exist)">Anglesey</a> (<i>Ynys Môn</i>) in the northwest.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Ireland" title="Geography of Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> accounts for just <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and is mostly hilly. It includes <a href="/wiki/Lough_Neagh" title="Lough Neagh">Lough Neagh</a> which, at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, is the largest lake in the British Isles by area.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[112]</a></sup> The highest peak in Northern Ireland is <a href="/wiki/Slieve_Donard" title="Slieve Donard">Slieve Donard</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mourne_Mountains" title="Mourne Mountains">Mourne Mountains</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_110-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-110">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The United Kingdom has a temperate climate, with plentiful rainfall all year round.<sup id="cite_ref-factbook_109-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-109">[101]</a></sup> The temperature varies with the seasons seldom dropping below <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> or rising above <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[113]</a></sup> The prevailing wind is from the south-west and bears frequent spells of mild and wet weather from the Atlantic Ocean,<sup id="cite_ref-factbook_109-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-109">[101]</a></sup> although the eastern parts are mostly sheltered from this wind since the majority of the rain falls over the western regions the eastern parts are therefore the driest. Atlantic currents, warmed by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gulf_Stream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gulf Stream (page does not exist)">Gulf Stream</a>, bring mild winters; especially in the west where winters are wet and even more so over high ground. Summers are warmest in the south-east of England, being closest to the European mainland, and coolest in the north. Heavy snowfall can occur in winter and early spring on high ground, and occasionally settles to great depth away from the hills.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_administrative_geography_of_the_United_Kingdom.png" title="File:Map of the administrative geography of the United Kingdom.png">File:Map of the administrative geography of the United Kingdom.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Administrative units of the United Kingdom</div></div></div>
<p>Each country of the United Kingdom has its own system of administrative and geographic demarcation, whose origins often pre-date the formation of the United Kingdom. Thus there is "no common stratum of administrative unit encompassing the United Kingdom".<sup id="cite_ref-UN_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN-122">[114]</a></sup> Until the 19th century there was little change to those arrangements, but there has since been a constant evolution of role and function.<sup id="cite_ref-barlow_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-barlow-123">[115]</a></sup> Change did not occur in a uniform manner and the devolution of power over local government to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland means that future changes are unlikely to be uniform either.
</p><p>The organisation of <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_England" title="Local government in England">local government in England</a> is complex, with the distribution of functions varying according to local arrangements. Legislation concerning local government in England is the responsibility of the UK parliament and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Government_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Government of the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Government of the United Kingdom</a>, as England has no devolved parliament. The upper-tier <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_England" title="Subdivisions of England">subdivisions of England</a> are the nine <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regions_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regions of England (page does not exist)">Government office regions</a> or European Union government office regions.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[116]</a></sup> One region, <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Authority" title="Greater London Authority">Greater London</a>, has had a directly elected assembly and mayor since 2000 following popular support for the proposal in a <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Authority_referendum,_1998" title="Greater London Authority referendum, 1998">referendum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[117]</a></sup> It was intended that other regions would also be given their own elected <a href="/wiki/Regional_assembly_(England)" title="Regional assembly (England)">regional assemblies</a>, but a proposed assembly in the <a href="/wiki/North_East_England" title="North East England">North East</a> region was rejected by a <a href="/wiki/Northern_England_devolution_referendums,_2004" title="Northern England devolution referendums, 2004">referendum in 2004</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[118]</a></sup> Below the regional tier, some parts of England have <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metropolitan_and_non-metropolitan_counties_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metropolitan and non-metropolitan counties of England (page does not exist)">county councils</a> and district councils and others have <a href="/wiki/Unitary_authorities" title="Unitary authorities" class="mw-redirect">unitary authorities</a>; while London consists of 32 <a href="/w/index.php?title=London_borough&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="London borough (page does not exist)">London boroughs</a> and the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>. Councillors are elected by the <a href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" title="Plurality voting system">first-past-the-post</a> system in single-member wards or by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plurality-at-large_voting&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plurality-at-large voting (page does not exist)">multi-member plurality system</a> in multi-member wards.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>For <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Scotland" title="Local government in Scotland">local government purposes</a>, Scotland is divided into <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Scotland" title="Subdivisions of Scotland">32 council areas</a>, with wide variation in both size and population. The cities of <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, Edinburgh, <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen" title="Aberdeen">Aberdeen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dundee" title="Dundee">Dundee</a> are separate council areas, as is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Politics_of_the_Highland_council_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Politics of the Highland council area (page does not exist)">Highland Council</a> which includes a third of Scotland's area but only just over 200,000&#160;people. Local councils are made up of elected councillors, of whom there are currently 1,222;<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[120]</a></sup> they are paid a part-time salary. Elections are conducted by <a href="/wiki/Single_transferable_vote" title="Single transferable vote">single transferable vote</a> in multi-member wards that elect either three or four councillors. Each council elects a <a href="/wiki/Provost_(civil)" title="Provost (civil)">Provost</a>, or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chairman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chairman (page does not exist)">Convenor</a>, to chair meetings of the council and to act as a figurehead for the area. <a href="/wiki/Councillor" title="Councillor">Councillors</a> are subject to a <a href="/wiki/Ethical_code" title="Ethical code">code of conduct</a> enforced by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Standards_Commission_for_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Standards Commission for Scotland (page does not exist)">Standards Commission for Scotland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[121]</a></sup> The representative association of Scotland's local authorities is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Convention_of_Scottish_Local_Authorities&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (page does not exist)">Convention of Scottish Local Authorities</a> (COSLA).<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Wales" title="Local government in Wales">Local government in Wales</a> consists of 22 unitary authorities. These include the cities of <a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swansea" title="Swansea">Swansea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Newport" title="Newport">Newport</a> which are unitary authorities in their own right.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[123]</a></sup> Elections are held every four years under the first-past-the-post system.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[124]</a></sup> The most recent elections were held in May 2012, except for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isle_of_Anglesey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isle of Anglesey (page does not exist)">Isle of Anglesey</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Welsh_Local_Government_Association&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Welsh Local Government Association (page does not exist)">Welsh Local Government Association</a> represents the interests of local authorities in Wales.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Local government in Northern Ireland">Local government in Northern Ireland</a> has since 1973 been organised into 26 district councils, each elected by single transferable vote. Their powers are limited to services such as collecting waste, controlling dogs and maintaining parks and cemeteries.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[126]</a></sup> On 13 March 2008 the executive agreed on proposals to create 11 new councils and replace the present system.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[127]</a></sup> The next local elections were postponed until 2016 to facilitate this.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[128]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dependencies">Dependencies</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Inside_the_Reef_Cayman.jpg" title="File:Inside the Reef Cayman.jpg">File:Inside the Reef Cayman.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A view of the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Cayman_Islands" title="Cayman Islands">Cayman Islands</a>, one of the world's foremost international financial centres<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[129]</a></sup> and tourist destinations.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[130]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The United Kingdom has sovereignty over seventeen territories which do not form part of the United Kingdom itself: fourteen British Overseas Territories<sup id="cite_ref-fco14Terr_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fco14Terr-139">[131]</a></sup> and three Crown Dependencies.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p>The fourteen British Overseas Territories are: <a href="/wiki/Anguilla" title="Anguilla">Anguilla</a>; <a href="/wiki/Bermuda" title="Bermuda">Bermuda</a>; the <a href="/wiki/British_Antarctic_Territory" title="British Antarctic Territory">British Antarctic Territory</a>; the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Indian_Ocean_Territory&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Indian Ocean Territory (page does not exist)">British Indian Ocean Territory</a>; the <a href="/wiki/British_Virgin_Islands" title="British Virgin Islands">British Virgin Islands</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Cayman_Islands" title="Cayman Islands">Cayman Islands</a>; the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Falkland_Islands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Falkland Islands (page does not exist)">Falkland Islands</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gibraltar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gibraltar (page does not exist)">Gibraltar</a>; <a href="/wiki/Montserrat" title="Montserrat">Montserrat</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Helena,_Ascension_and_Tristan_da_Cunha&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha (page does not exist)">Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Turks_and_Caicos_Islands" title="Turks and Caicos Islands">Turks and Caicos Islands</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Pitcairn_Islands" title="Pitcairn Islands">Pitcairn Islands</a>; <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Akrotiri_and_Dhekelia" title="Akrotiri and Dhekelia">Sovereign Base Areas on Cyprus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[133]</a></sup> British claims in Antarctica are not universally recognised.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[134]</a></sup> Collectively Britain's overseas territories encompass an approximate land area of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and a population of approximately 260,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[135]</a></sup> They are the remnants of the British Empire and several have specifically voted to remain British territories (Bermuda in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bermudan_independence_referendum,_1995&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bermudan independence referendum, 1995 (page does not exist)">1995</a>, Gibraltar in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gibraltar_sovereignty_referendum,_2002&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gibraltar sovereignty referendum, 2002 (page does not exist)">2002</a> and the Falkland Islands in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Falkland_Islands_sovereignty_referendum,_2013&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Falkland Islands sovereignty referendum, 2013 (page does not exist)">2013</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Independent_results_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Independent_results-144">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Crown Dependencies are British possessions of <a href="/wiki/The_Crown" title="The Crown">the Crown</a>, as opposed to overseas territories of the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[137]</a></sup> They comprise the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Islands" title="Channel Islands">Channel Island</a> <a href="/wiki/Bailiwick" title="Bailiwick">Bailiwicks</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jersey" title="Jersey">Jersey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guernsey" title="Guernsey">Guernsey</a> in the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">Isle of Man</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Irish_Sea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irish Sea (page does not exist)">Irish Sea</a>.
