Being independently administered jurisdictions they do not form <a href="/w/index.php?title=Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Countries of the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">part of the United Kingdom</a> or of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, although the UK government manages their foreign affairs and defence and the UK Parliament has the authority to legislate on their behalf. The power to pass legislation affecting the islands ultimately rests with their own respective legislative assemblies, with the assent of the Crown (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Her_Majesty%27s_Most_Honourable_Privy_Council&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council (page does not exist)">Privy Council</a> or, in the case of the Isle of Man, in certain circumstances the Lieutenant-Governor).<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[138]</a></sup> Since 2005 each Crown dependency has had a <a href="/wiki/Chief_Minister" title="Chief Minister">Chief Minister</a> as its <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Elizabeth_II_greets_NASA_GSFC_employees,_May_8,_2007_edit.jpg" title="File:Elizabeth II greets NASA GSFC employees, May 8, 2007 edit.jpg">File:Elizabeth II greets NASA GSFC employees, May 8, 2007 edit.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth II (page does not exist)">Elizabeth II</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Queen of the United Kingdom" class="mw-redirect">Queen of the United Kingdom</a> and the other <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realms" title="Commonwealth realms" class="mw-redirect">Commonwealth realms</a></div></div></div>
<p>The United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a> under a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth II (page does not exist)">Queen Elizabeth II</a> is the head of state of the UK as well as monarch of fifteen other independent <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realm" title="Commonwealth realm">Commonwealth countries</a>. The monarch has "the right to be consulted, the right to encourage, and the right to warn".<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[140]</a></sup> The United Kingdom is one of only four countries in the world to have an <a href="/wiki/Uncodified_constitution" title="Uncodified constitution">uncodified constitution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[nb 9]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Constitution_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Constitution of the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Constitution of the United Kingdom</a> thus consists mostly of a collection of disparate written sources, including <a href="/wiki/Statute" title="Statute">statutes</a>, judge-made <a href="/wiki/Case_law" title="Case law" class="mw-redirect">case law</a> and international treaties, together with <a href="/wiki/British_Constitution#Conventions" title="British Constitution" class="mw-redirect">constitutional conventions</a>. As there is no technical difference between ordinary statutes and "constitutional law", the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">UK Parliament</a> can perform "constitutional reform" simply by passing <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Parliament" title="Act of Parliament">Acts of Parliament</a>, and thus has the political power to change or abolish almost any written or unwritten element of the constitution. However, no Parliament can pass laws that future Parliaments cannot change.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[142]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The UK has a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary government</a> based on the <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster system</a> that has been emulated around the world: a legacy of the British Empire. The parliament of the United Kingdom that meets in the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a> has two houses; an elected <a href="/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="House of Commons of the United Kingdom">House of Commons</a> and an appointed <a href="/wiki/House_of_Lords" title="House of Lords">House of Lords</a>. All bills passed are given <a href="/wiki/Royal_Assent" title="Royal Assent">Royal Assent</a> before becoming law.
</p><p>The position of <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">prime minister</a>, the UK's <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[143]</a></sup> belongs to the member of parliament who can obtain the confidence of a majority in the House of Commons, usually the leader of the largest political party in that chamber. The prime minister chooses a cabinet and they are formally appointed by the monarch to form <a href="/w/index.php?title=Government_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Government of the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Her Majesty's Government</a>. By convention, the Queen respects the prime minister's decisions of government.<sup id="cite_ref-npm_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-npm-153">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Palace_of_Westminster,_London_-_Feb_2007.jpg" title="File:Palace of Westminster, London - Feb 2007.jpg">File:Palace of Westminster, London - Feb 2007.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>, seat of both houses of the Parliament of the United Kingdom</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Cabinet of the United Kingdom">cabinet</a> is traditionally drawn from members of the Prime Minister's party in both legislative houses, and mostly from the House of Commons, to which <a href="/wiki/Responsible_government" title="Responsible government">they are responsible</a>. Executive power is exercised by the prime minister and cabinet, all of whom are sworn into the <a href="/wiki/Privy_Council_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Privy Council of the United Kingdom">Privy Council of the United Kingdom</a>, and become <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_the_Crown" title="Minister of the Crown">Ministers of the Crown</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Rt._Hon." title="Rt. Hon." class="mw-redirect">Rt. Hon.</a> <a href="/wiki/David_Cameron" title="David Cameron">David Cameron</a>, leader of the <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">Conservative Party</a>, heads a coalition with the UK's third party, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Liberal_Democrats&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Liberal Democrats (page does not exist)">Liberal Democrats</a>. Cameron has been Prime Minister, <a href="/wiki/First_Lord_of_the_Treasury" title="First Lord of the Treasury">First Lord of the Treasury</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_the_Civil_Service" title="Minister for the Civil Service">Minister for the Civil Service</a> since 11 May 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[145]</a></sup> For elections to the House of Commons, the UK is currently divided into <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_constituencies" title="United Kingdom constituencies">650 constituencies</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Elections_and_voting.C2.A0.E2.80.94_UK_Parliament_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elections_and_voting.C2.A0.E2.80.94_UK_Parliament-155">[146]</a></sup> each electing a single member of parliament by <a href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" title="Plurality voting system">simple plurality</a>. General elections are called by the monarch when the prime minister so advises. The <a href="/wiki/Parliament_Acts_1911_and_1949" title="Parliament Acts 1911 and 1949">Parliament Acts 1911 and 1949</a> require that a new election must be called no later than five years after the previous general election.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Parliament_Acts.C2.A0.E2.80.94_UK_Parliament_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Parliament_Acts.C2.A0.E2.80.94_UK_Parliament-156">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK's three <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_the_United_Kingdom#Major_parties_in_the_House_of_Commons" title="List of political parties in the United Kingdom">major political parties</a> are the Conservative Party, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Labour_Party_(UK)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Labour Party (UK) (page does not exist)">Labour Party</a> and the Liberal Democrats. During the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_2010" title="United Kingdom general election, 2010">2010 general election</a> these three parties won 622 out of 650 seats available in the House of Commons.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[148]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[149]</a></sup> Most of the remaining seats were won by parties that contest elections only in one part of the UK: the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_National_Party" title="Scottish National Party">Scottish National Party</a> (Scotland only); <a href="/wiki/Plaid_Cymru" title="Plaid Cymru">Plaid Cymru</a> (Wales only); and the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Unionist_Party" title="Democratic Unionist Party">Democratic Unionist Party</a>, <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_and_Labour_Party" title="Social Democratic and Labour Party">Social Democratic and Labour Party</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ulster_Unionist_Party" title="Ulster Unionist Party">Ulster Unionist Party</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sinn_F%C3%A9in" title="Sinn Féin">Sinn Féin</a> (Northern Ireland only, though Sinn Féin also contests elections in the Republic of Ireland). In accordance with party policy, no elected Sinn Féin members of parliament have ever attended the House of Commons to speak on behalf of their constituents because of the requirement to take an oath of allegiance to the monarch. The current five Sinn Féin MPs have, however, made use of offices and other facilities available at Westminster.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[150]</a></sup> For elections to the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a>, the UK currently has <a href="/w/index.php?title=Members_of_the_European_Parliament_for_the_United_Kingdom_2009%E2%80%932014&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Members of the European Parliament for the United Kingdom 2009–2014 (page does not exist)">72 MEPs</a>, elected in 12 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Multi-member&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Multi-member (page does not exist)">multi-member</a> constituencies.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[151]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Devolved_administrations">Devolved administrations</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Scotland_Parliament_Holyrood.jpg" title="File:Scotland Parliament Holyrood.jpg">File:Scotland Parliament Holyrood.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament_Building" title="Scottish Parliament Building">Scottish Parliament Building</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Holyrood,_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holyrood, Edinburgh (page does not exist)">Holyrood</a> is the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">Scottish Parliament</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have their own devolved  <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">government or executive</a>, led by a <a href="/wiki/First_Minister" title="First Minister">First Minister</a> (or, in the case of Northern Ireland, a <a href="/wiki/Diarchy" title="Diarchy">diarchal</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=First_Minister_and_deputy_First_Minister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="First Minister and deputy First Minister (page does not exist)">First Minister and deputy First Minister</a>), and a <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved</a> <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral</a> legislature. England, the largest country of the United Kingdom, has no such devolved executive or legislature and is administered and legislated for directly by the UK government and parliament on all issues. This situation has given rise to the so-called <a href="/wiki/West_Lothian_question" title="West Lothian question">West Lothian question</a> which concerns the fact that MPs from Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland can vote, sometimes decisively,<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[152]</a></sup> on matters that only affect England.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[153]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Commission_on_the_consequences_of_devolution_for_the_House_of_Commons&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Commission on the consequences of devolution for the House of Commons (page does not exist)">McKay Commission</a> reported on this matter in March 2013 recommending that laws affecting only England should need support from a majority of English MPs.<sup id="cite_ref-bbcnews250313_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbcnews250313-163">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">Parliament</a> have wide-ranging powers over any matter that has not been specifically <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reserved_matters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reserved matters (page does not exist)">reserved</a> to the UK parliament, including <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Scotland" title="Education in Scotland">education</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=NHS_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NHS Scotland (page does not exist)">healthcare</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scots_law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scots law (page does not exist)">Scots law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Scotland" title="Local government in Scotland">local government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[155]</a></sup> At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_Parliament_general_election,_2011&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish Parliament general election, 2011 (page does not exist)">2011 elections</a> the SNP won re-election and achieved an overall majority in the Scottish parliament, with its leader, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alex_Salmond&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alex Salmond (page does not exist)">Alex Salmond</a>, as <a href="/wiki/First_Minister_of_Scotland" title="First Minister of Scotland">First Minister of Scotland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[156]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[157]</a></sup> In 2012, the UK and Scottish governments signed the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edinburgh_Agreement_(2012)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edinburgh Agreement (2012) (page does not exist)">Edinburgh Agreement</a> setting out the terms for a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_independence_referendum,_2014&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish independence referendum, 2014 (page does not exist)">referendum on Scottish independence</a> in 2014.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Government" title="Welsh Government">Welsh Government</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_for_Wales" title="National Assembly for Wales">National Assembly for Wales</a> have more limited powers than those devolved to Scotland.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[158]</a></sup> The Assembly is able to legislate on devolved matters through <a href="/w/index.php?title=Act_of_the_National_Assembly_for_Wales&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Act of the National Assembly for Wales (page does not exist)">Acts of the Assembly</a>, which require no prior consent from Westminster. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Assembly_for_Wales_election,_2011&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Assembly for Wales election, 2011 (page does not exist)">2011 elections</a> resulted in a minority Labour administration led by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carwyn_Jones&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carwyn Jones (page does not exist)">Carwyn Jones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IcWales_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IcWales-168">[159]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">Northern Ireland Executive</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Assembly" title="Northern Ireland Assembly">Assembly</a> have powers similar to those devolved to Scotland. The Executive is led by a <a href="/wiki/Diarchy" title="Diarchy">diarchy</a> representing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Designated_Unionist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Designated Unionist (page does not exist)">unionist</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Designated_Nationalist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Designated Nationalist (page does not exist)">nationalist</a> members of the Assembly. Currently, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Robinson_(politician)" title="Peter Robinson (politician)">Peter Robinson</a> (<a href="/wiki/Democratic_Unionist_Party" title="Democratic Unionist Party">Democratic Unionist Party</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Martin_McGuinness" title="Martin McGuinness">Martin McGuinness</a> (<a href="/wiki/Sinn_F%C3%A9in" title="Sinn Féin">Sinn Féin</a>) are <a href="/w/index.php?title=First_Minister_and_deputy_First_Minister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="First Minister and deputy First Minister (page does not exist)">First Minister and deputy First Minister</a> respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-northernireland1_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-northernireland1-169">[160]</a></sup> Devolution to Northern Ireland is contingent on participation by the Northern Ireland administration in the <a href="/wiki/North-South_Ministerial_Council" title="North-South Ministerial Council" class="mw-redirect">North-South Ministerial Council</a>, where the Northern Ireland Executive cooperates and develops joint and shared policies with the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ireland" title="Government of Ireland">Government of Ireland</a>. The British and Irish governments co-operate on non-devolved matters affecting Northern Ireland through the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British%E2%80%93Irish_Intergovernmental_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British–Irish Intergovernmental Conference (page does not exist)">British–Irish Intergovernmental Conference</a>, which assumes the responsibilities of the Northern Ireland administration in the event of its non-operation.
</p><p>The UK does not have a <a href="/wiki/Codified_constitution" title="Codified constitution" class="mw-redirect">codified constitution</a> and constitutional matters are not among the powers devolved to Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland. Under the doctrine of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Parliamentary_sovereignty_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Parliamentary sovereignty in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">parliamentary sovereignty</a>, the UK Parliament could, in theory, therefore, abolish the Scottish Parliament, Welsh Assembly or Northern Ireland Assembly.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[162]</a></sup> Indeed, in 1972, the UK Parliament <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Ireland_(Temporary_Provisions)_Act_1972&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Ireland (Temporary Provisions) Act 1972 (page does not exist)">unilaterally prorogued</a> the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Northern_Ireland" title="Parliament of Northern Ireland">Parliament of Northern Ireland</a>, setting a precedent relevant to contemporary devolved institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[163]</a></sup> In practice, it would be politically difficult for the UK Parliament to abolish devolution to the Scottish Parliament and the Welsh Assembly, given the political entrenchment created by referendum decisions.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[164]</a></sup> The political constraints placed upon the UK Parliament's power to interfere with devolution in Northern Ireland are even greater than in relation to Scotland and Wales, given that devolution in Northern Ireland rests upon an international agreement with the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ireland" title="Government of Ireland">Government of Ireland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[165]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_criminal_justice">Law and criminal justice</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_courts_of_justice.jpg" title="File:Royal courts of justice.jpg">File:Royal courts of justice.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Courts_of_Justice" title="Royal Courts of Justice">Royal Courts of Justice</a> of <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a></div></div></div>
<p>The United Kingdom does not have a single legal system, as Article 19 of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treaty of Union (page does not exist)">1706 Treaty of Union</a> provided for the continuation of Scotland's separate legal system.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[166]</a></sup> Today the UK has three distinct <a href="/w/index.php?title=Legal_systems_of_the_world&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Legal systems of the world (page does not exist)">systems of law</a>: <a href="/wiki/English_law" title="English law">English law</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Courts_of_Northern_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Courts of Northern Ireland (page does not exist)">Northern Ireland law</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scots_law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scots law (page does not exist)">Scots law</a>. A new <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Supreme Court of the United Kingdom">Supreme Court of the United Kingdom</a> came into being in October 2009 to replace the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_functions_of_the_House_of_Lords" title="Judicial functions of the House of Lords">Appellate Committee of the House of Lords</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[167]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[168]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Judicial_Committee_of_the_Privy_Council" title="Judicial Committee of the Privy Council">Judicial Committee of the Privy Council</a>, including the same members as the Supreme Court, is the highest court of appeal for several independent Commonwealth countries, the <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">British Overseas Territories</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crown_Dependencies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crown Dependencies (page does not exist)">Crown Dependencies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both English law, which applies in <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Ireland_law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Ireland law (page does not exist)">Northern Ireland law</a> are based on <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">common-law</a> principles.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[170]</a></sup> The essence of common law is that, subject to statute, the law is developed by judges in courts, applying statute, <a href="/wiki/Precedent" title="Precedent">precedent</a> and common sense to the facts before them to give explanatory judgements of the relevant legal principles, which are reported and binding in future similar cases (<i><a href="/wiki/Stare_decisis" title="Stare decisis" class="mw-redirect">stare decisis</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[171]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Courts_of_England_and_Wales" title="Courts of England and Wales">courts of England and Wales</a> are headed by the <a href="/wiki/Senior_Courts_of_England_and_Wales" title="Senior Courts of England and Wales" class="mw-redirect">Senior Courts of England and Wales</a>, consisting of the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Appeal_of_England_and_Wales" title="Court of Appeal of England and Wales">Court of Appeal</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=High_Court_of_Justice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="High Court of Justice (page does not exist)">High Court of Justice</a> (for civil cases) and the <a href="/wiki/Crown_Court" title="Crown Court">Crown Court</a> (for criminal cases). The Supreme Court is the highest court in the land for both criminal and civil appeal cases in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and any decision it makes is binding on every other court in the same jurisdiction, often having a persuasive effect in other jurisdictions.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg" title="File:High Court of Justiciary.jpg">File:High Court of Justiciary.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justiciary" title="High Court of Justiciary">High Court of Justiciary</a>&#160;– the <a href="/w/index.php?title=College_of_Justice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="College of Justice (page does not exist)">supreme</a> <a href="/wiki/Criminal_justice" title="Criminal justice">criminal court</a> of <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Scots law is a hybrid system based on both common-law and <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil-law</a> principles. The chief courts are the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Session" title="Court of Session">Court of Session</a>, for civil cases,<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[173]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justiciary" title="High Court of Justiciary">High Court of Justiciary</a>, for criminal cases.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[174]</a></sup> The Supreme Court of the United Kingdom serves as the highest court of appeal for civil cases under Scots law.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[175]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sheriff_Court&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sheriff Court (page does not exist)">Sheriff courts</a> deal with most civil and criminal cases including conducting criminal trials with a jury, known as sheriff solemn court, or with a sheriff and no jury, known as sheriff summary Court.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[176]</a></sup> The Scots legal system is unique in having three possible <a href="/wiki/Verdict" title="Verdict">verdicts</a> for a criminal trial: "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Guilt_(law)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guilt (law) (page does not exist)">guilty</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Acquittal" title="Acquittal">not guilty</a>" and "<i><a href="/wiki/Not_proven" title="Not proven">not proven</a></i>". Both "not guilty" and "not proven" result in an acquittal.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[177]</a></sup>
</p><p>Crime in England and Wales increased in the period between 1981 and 1995, though since that peak there has been an overall fall of 48% in crime from 1995 to 2007/08,<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[178]</a></sup> according to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crime_statistics_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crime statistics in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">crime statistics</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prison_population_of_England_and_Wales&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prison population of England and Wales (page does not exist)">prison population of England and Wales</a> has almost doubled over the same period, to over 80,000, giving England and Wales the highest rate of incarceration in Western Europe at 147 per 100,000.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[179]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Prison_Service" title="Her Majesty's Prison Service">Her Majesty's Prison Service</a>, which reports to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ministry_of_Justice_(United_Kingdom)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom) (page does not exist)">Ministry of Justice</a>, manages most of the prisons within England and Wales. Crime in Scotland fell to its lowest recorded level for 32 years in 2009/10, falling by ten per cent.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[180]</a></sup> At the same time Scotland's prison population, at over 8,000,<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[181]</a></sup> is at record levels and well above design capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[182]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_Prison_Service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish Prison Service (page does not exist)">Scottish Prison Service</a>, which reports to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cabinet_Secretary_for_Justice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cabinet Secretary for Justice (page does not exist)">Cabinet Secretary for Justice</a>, manages Scotland's prisons. In 2006 a report by the Surveillance Studies Network found that the UK had the highest level of <a href="/wiki/Mass_surveillance" title="Mass surveillance">mass surveillance</a> among industrialised western nations.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[183]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:David_Cameron_and_Barack_Obama_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Toronto.jpg" title="File:David Cameron and Barack Obama at the G20 Summit in Toronto.jpg">File:David Cameron and Barack Obama at the G20 Summit in Toronto.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, <a href="/wiki/David_Cameron" title="David Cameron">David Cameron</a>, and the President of the United States, <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a>, during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_G-20_Toronto_summit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 G-20 Toronto summit (page does not exist)">2010 G-20 Toronto summit</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The UK is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Big_Five_(United_Nations)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Big Five (United Nations) (page does not exist)">permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>, a member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Commonwealth of Nations (page does not exist)">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a>, <a href="/wiki/G8" title="G8">G8</a>, <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (page does not exist)">OECD</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>, and is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Member_state_of_the_European_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Member state of the European Union (page does not exist)">member state of the European Union</a>. The UK is said to have a "<a href="/wiki/Special_Relationship" title="Special Relationship">Special Relationship</a>" with the United States<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[184]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[185]</a></sup> and a close partnership with France—the "<a href="/wiki/Entente_cordiale" title="Entente cordiale">Entente cordiale</a>"—and shares nuclear weapons technology with both countries. The UK is also closely linked with the Republic of Ireland; the two countries share a <a href="/wiki/Common_Travel_Area" title="Common Travel Area">Common Travel Area</a> and co-operate through the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British-Irish_Intergovernmental_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference (page does not exist)">British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British-Irish_Council&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British-Irish Council (page does not exist)">British-Irish Council</a>. Britain's global presence and influence is further amplified through its trading relations, foreign investments, <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">official development assistance</a> and military engagements.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[186]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:British_Tri-Service_equipment.jpg" title="File:British Tri-Service equipment.jpg">File:British Tri-Service equipment.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Type_45_destroyer" title="Type 45 destroyer">Type 45 destroyer</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Challenger_2" title="Challenger 2">Challenger 2</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Eurofighter" title="Eurofighter" class="mw-redirect">Eurofighter</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The <a href="/wiki/Armed_forces" title="Armed forces">armed forces</a> of the United Kingdom – also known as <i><a href="/wiki/British_Armed_Forces" title="British Armed Forces">Her Majesty's Armed Forces</a></i> or the <i>Armed Forces of the Crown.</i><sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[187]</a></sup> – consist of three professional service branches: the <a href="/wiki/Naval_Service_(United_Kingdom)" title="Naval Service (United Kingdom)">Naval Service</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Marines" title="Royal Marines">Royal Marines</a> and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Fleet_Auxiliary" title="Royal Fleet Auxiliary">Royal Fleet Auxiliary</a>), the <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British Army</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">Royal Air Force</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[188]</a></sup> The forces are managed by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(United_Kingdom)" title="Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)">Ministry of Defence</a> and controlled by the <a href="/wiki/Defence_Council_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Defence Council of the United Kingdom">Defence Council</a>, chaired by the <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Defence" title="Secretary of State for Defence">Secretary of State for Defence</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Commander-in-Chief&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Commander-in-Chief (page does not exist)">Commander-in-Chief</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">British monarch</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Speaker_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Speaker-198">[189]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth II (page does not exist)">Elizabeth II</a>, to whom members of the forces swear an oath of allegiance.
</p><p>According to various sources, including the <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a> and the Ministry of Defence, the United Kingdom has the fourth-highest <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by military expenditures (page does not exist)">military expenditure</a> in the world. Total defence spending currently accounts for around 2.3&#160;– 2.6% of total national GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Armed Forces are charged with protecting the UK and its overseas territories, promoting the UK's global security interests and supporting international peacekeeping efforts. They are active and regular participants in <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Headquarters_Allied_Rapid_Reaction_Corps" title="Headquarters Allied Rapid Reaction Corps">Allied Rapid Reaction Corps</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Five_Power_Defence_Arrangements" title="Five Power Defence Arrangements">Five Power Defence Arrangements</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=RIMPAC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RIMPAC (page does not exist)">RIMPAC</a> and other worldwide coalition operations. Overseas garrisons and facilities are maintained in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ascension_Island&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ascension Island (page does not exist)">Ascension Island</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Military_of_Belize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Military of Belize (page does not exist)">Belize</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Military_Forces_based_in_Brunei&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Military Forces based in Brunei (page does not exist)">Brunei</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Army_Training_Unit_Suffield" title="British Army Training Unit Suffield">Canada</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sovereign_Base_Areas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sovereign Base Areas (page does not exist)">Cyprus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diego_Garcia" title="Diego Garcia">Diego Garcia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Military_of_the_Falkland_Islands" title="Military of the Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Forces_Germany" title="British Forces Germany">Germany</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Forces_Gibraltar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Forces Gibraltar (page does not exist)">Gibraltar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kenya" title="Kenya">Kenya</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Qatar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Qatar (page does not exist)">Qatar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Facilities_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Facilities-200">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Royal Navy is a prominent <a href="/wiki/Blue-water_navy" title="Blue-water navy">blue-water navy</a>, currently one of only three world wide, with the <a href="/wiki/French_Navy" title="French Navy">French Navy</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Navy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Navy (page does not exist)">United States Navy</a> being the other two.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[192]</a></sup> As well as being responsible for delivering the UK's nuclear deterrent via the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UK_Trident_programme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UK Trident programme (page does not exist)">UK Trident programme</a> and four <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vanguard_class_submarine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vanguard class submarine (page does not exist)">Vanguard class submarines</a>, the Royal Navy operates a large operational fleet of ships, including an <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carrier</a>, a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amphibious_assault_ship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amphibious assault ship (page does not exist)">helicopter carrier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Landing_platform_dock" title="Landing platform dock" class="mw-redirect">landing platform docks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_submarine" title="Nuclear submarine">nuclear fleet submarines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guided_missile_destroyer" title="Guided missile destroyer">guided missile destroyers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frigate" title="Frigate">frigates</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mine-countermeasure_vessel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mine-countermeasure vessel (page does not exist)">mine-countermeasure vessels</a> and <a href="/wiki/Patrol_boat" title="Patrol boat">patrol vessels</a>. In the near future two new <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carriers</a>, <a href="/wiki/HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_(R08)" title="HMS Queen Elizabeth (R08)">HMS <i>Queen Elizabeth</i></a> and <a href="/wiki/HMS_Prince_of_Wales_(R09)" title="HMS Prince of Wales (R09)">HMS <i>Prince of Wales</i></a> will enter service in the Royal Navy. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom_Special_Forces&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Kingdom Special Forces (page does not exist)">United Kingdom Special Forces</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Special_Air_Service" title="Special Air Service">Special Air Service</a> and <a href="/wiki/Special_Boat_Service" title="Special Boat Service">Special Boat Service</a>, provide troops trained for quick, mobile, military responses in <a href="/wiki/Counter-terrorism" title="Counter-terrorism">counter-terrorism</a>, land, maritime and <a href="/wiki/Amphibious_warfare" title="Amphibious warfare">amphibious operations</a>, often where secrecy or covert tactics are required.
</p><p>Historically, the British armed forces played a key role in establishing the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Superpower" title="Superpower">dominant world power</a> in the 19th century. British forces have seen action in a number of major wars, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seven_Years%27_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seven Years' War (page does not exist)">Seven Years' War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_War" title="Crimean War">Crimean War</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a> and <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>—as well as many colonial conflicts. Through its military strength, Britain has often been able to decisively <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">influence world events</a>. Since the end of the British Empire, the UK has nonetheless remained a major military power. The British military is among the largest and most technologically sophisticated in the world. Recent defence policy has a stated assumption that "the most demanding operations" will be undertaken as part of a coalition.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[193]</a></sup> Setting aside the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Palliser" title="Operation Palliser" class="mw-redirect">intervention in Sierra Leone</a>, recent UK military operations in <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_War" title="Bosnian War">Bosnia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_War" title="Kosovo War">Kosovo</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Role_of_the_United_Kingdom_in_the_War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Role of the United Kingdom in the War in Afghanistan (2001–present) (page does not exist)">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Operation_Telic" title="Operation Telic">Iraq</a> and, most recently, <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_military_intervention_in_Libya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 military intervention in Libya (page does not exist)">Libya</a>, have followed this approach. The last time the British military fought alone was the <a href="/wiki/Falklands_War" title="Falklands War">Falklands War</a> of 1982.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:London.bankofengland.arp.jpg" title="File:London.bankofengland.arp.jpg">File:London.bankofengland.arp.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a>&#160;– the <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">central bank</a> of the United Kingdom</div></div></div>
<p>The UK has a partially regulated <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[194]</a></sup> Based on market <a href="/wiki/Exchange_rate" title="Exchange rate">exchange rates</a> the UK is today the sixth-largest economy in the world and the third-largest in Europe after Germany and France, having fallen behind France for the first time in over a decade in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-GDP_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GDP-204">[195]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/HM_Treasury" title="HM Treasury">HM Treasury</a>, led by the <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_of_the_Exchequer" title="Chancellor of the Exchequer">Chancellor of the Exchequer</a>, is responsible for developing and executing the British government's <a href="/wiki/Public_finance" title="Public finance">public finance</a> policy and <a href="/wiki/Economic_policy" title="Economic policy">economic policy</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a> is the UK's <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">central bank</a> and is responsible for issuing notes and coins in the nation's currency, the <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">pound sterling</a>. Banks in Scotland and Northern Ireland retain the right to issue their own notes, subject to retaining enough Bank of England notes in reserve to cover their issue. Pound sterling is the world's third-largest <a href="/wiki/Reserve_currency" title="Reserve currency">reserve currency</a> (after the U.S. Dollar and the Euro).<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[196]</a></sup> Since 1997 the Bank of England's <a href="/wiki/Monetary_Policy_Committee" title="Monetary Policy Committee">Monetary Policy Committee</a>, headed by the <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_the_Bank_of_England" title="Governor of the Bank of England">Governor of the Bank of England</a>, has been responsible for setting <a href="/w/index.php?title=Official_bank_rate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Official bank rate (page does not exist)">interest rates</a> at the level necessary to achieve the overall inflation target for the economy that is set by the Chancellor each year.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service sector</a> makes up around 73% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[198]</a></sup> London is one of the three "command centres" of <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">the global economy</a> (alongside New York City and Tokyo),<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[199]</a></sup> is the world's largest financial centre alongside New York,<sup id="cite_ref-Global_Financial_Centres_7_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Financial_Centres_7-209">[200]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mastercard_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mastercard-210">[201]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-forbes.com_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forbes.com-211">[202]</a></sup> and has the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_cities_by_GDP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of cities by GDP (page does not exist)">largest city GDP</a> in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Global_city_GDP_rankings_2008-2025_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Global_city_GDP_rankings_2008-2025-212">[203]</a></sup> Edinburgh is also one of the largest financial centres in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[204]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Tourism in the United Kingdom">Tourism</a> is very important to the British economy and, with over 27&#160;million tourists arriving in 2004, the United Kingdom is ranked as the sixth major tourist destination in the world<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[205]</a></sup> and London has the most international visitors of any city in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[206]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Creative_industries" title="Creative industries">creative industries</a> accounted for 7% GVA in 2005 and grew at an average of 6% per annum between 1997 and 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[207]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:A350_First_Flight_-_Low_pass_02.jpg" title="File:A350 First Flight - Low pass 02.jpg">File:A350 First Flight - Low pass 02.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Airbus_A350&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Airbus A350 (page does not exist)">Airbus A350</a> has its wings and engines manufactured in the UK.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> started in the UK<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa-217">[208]</a></sup> with an initial concentration on the textile industry, followed by other heavy industries such as <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding" title="Shipbuilding">shipbuilding</a>, coal mining and <a href="/wiki/Steelmaking" title="Steelmaking">steelmaking</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[210]</a></sup>
The empire was exploited as an overseas market for British products, allowing the UK to dominate international trade in the 19th century. As other nations industrialised, coupled with economic decline after two world wars, the United Kingdom began to lose its competitive advantage and heavy industry declined, by degrees, throughout the 20th century. Manufacturing remains a significant part of the economy but accounted for only 16.7% of national output in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[211]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Automotive industry in the United Kingdom">automotive industry</a> is a significant part of the UK manufacturing sector and employs over 800,000 people, with a turnover of some £52 billion, generating £26.6 billion of exports.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[212]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aerospace_industry_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aerospace industry in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">aerospace industry of the UK</a> is the second- or third-largest national aerospace industry depending upon the method of measurement and has an annual turnover of around £20 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-asd_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-asd-223">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ads_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ads-224">[215]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pharmaceutical_industry_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pharmaceutical industry in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">pharmaceutical industry</a> plays an important role in the UK economy and the country has the third highest share of global pharmaceutical R&amp;D expenditures (after the United States and Japan).<sup id="cite_ref-pharmsectorbis_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pharmsectorbis-225">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>Agriculture is intensive, highly mechanised and efficient by European standards, producing about 60% of food needs with less than 1.6% of the labour force (535,000 workers).<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[218]</a></sup> Around two-thirds of  production is devoted to livestock, one-third to arable crops.  Farmers are subsidised by the EU's <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a>. The UK retains a significant, though much reduced fishing industry. It is also rich in a number of natural resources including coal, petroleum, natural gas, tin, limestone, iron ore, salt, clay, chalk, gypsum, lead, silica and an abundance of arable land.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:City_of_London_skyline_at_dusk.jpg" title="File:City of London skyline at dusk.jpg">File:City of London skyline at dusk.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a> is the world's largest <a href="/wiki/International_financial_centre" title="International financial centre" class="mw-redirect">financial centre</a> alongside <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York</a><sup id="cite_ref-Global_Financial_Centres_7_209-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Financial_Centres_7-209">[200]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mastercard_210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mastercard-210">[201]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-forbes.com_211-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forbes.com-211">[202]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In the final quarter of 2008 the UK economy officially entered <a href="/w/index.php?title=Late-2000s_recession&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Late-2000s recession (page does not exist)">recession</a> for the first time since 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[219]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Unemployment_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unemployment in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Unemployment</a> increased from 5.2% in May 2008 to 7.6% in May 2009 and by January 2012 the unemployment rate among 18 to 24-year-olds had risen from 11.9% to 22.5%, the highest since current records began in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[220]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[221]</a></sup> Total UK <a href="/wiki/Government_debt" title="Government debt">government debt</a> rose from 44.4% of GDP in 2007 to 82.9% of GDP in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[222]</a></sup> In February 2013, the UK lost its top AAA credit rating for the first time since 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">Inflation</a>-adjusted wages in the UK fell by 3.2% between the third quarter of 2010 and the third quarter of 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-PAwages_233-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PAwages-233">[224]</a></sup> Since the 1980s, <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">economic inequality</a> has grown faster in the UK than in any other developed country.<sup id="cite_ref-Beckford_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beckford-234">[225]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poverty_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poverty in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">poverty line in the UK</a> is commonly defined as being 60% of the median household income.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[nb 10]</a></sup> In 2007–2008 13.5&#160;million people, or 22% of the population, lived below this line. This is a higher level of <a href="/wiki/Relative_poverty" title="Relative poverty" class="mw-redirect">relative poverty</a> than all but four other EU members.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[226]</a></sup> In the same year 4.0&#160;million children, 31% of the total, lived in households below the poverty line after housing costs were taken into account. This is a decrease of 400,000 children since 1998–1999.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[227]</a></sup> The UK imports 40% of its food supplies.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[228]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a> has estimated that in 2011, 14 million people were at risk of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poverty_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poverty in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">poverty</a> or social exclusion, and that one person in 20 (5.1%) was now experiencing "severe material depression,"<sup id="cite_ref-Andrews_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Andrews-239">[229]</a></sup> up from 3 million people in 1977.<sup id="cite_ref-Glynn_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Glynn-240">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Physorg_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Physorg-241">[231]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Charles_Darwin_01.jpg" title="File:Charles Darwin 01.jpg">File:Charles Darwin 01.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Darwin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Darwin (page does not exist)">Charles Darwin</a> (1809–82), whose theory of <a href="/wiki/Evolution" title="Evolution">evolution by natural selection</a> is the foundation of modern biological sciences</div></div></div>
<p>England and Scotland were leading centres of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scientific_Revolution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scientific Revolution (page does not exist)">Scientific Revolution</a> from the 17th century<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[232]</a></sup> and the United Kingdom led the Industrial Revolution from the 18th century,<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_217-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa-217">[208]</a></sup> and has continued to produce scientists and engineers credited with important advances.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[233]</a></sup> Major theorists from the 17th and 18th centuries include <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Newton" title="Isaac Newton">Isaac Newton</a>, whose <a href="/wiki/Newton%27s_laws_of_motion" title="Newton's laws of motion">laws of motion</a> and illumination of <a href="/wiki/Gravitation" title="Gravitation">gravity</a> have been seen as a keystone of modern science,<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[234]</a></sup> from the 19th century <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Darwin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Darwin (page does not exist)">Charles Darwin</a>, whose theory of <a href="/wiki/Evolution" title="Evolution">evolution</a> by <a href="/wiki/Natural_selection" title="Natural selection">natural selection</a> was fundamental to the development of modern biology, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Clerk_Maxwell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Clerk Maxwell (page does not exist)">James Clerk Maxwell</a>, who formulated classical <a href="/wiki/Electromagnetic_theory" title="Electromagnetic theory" class="mw-redirect">electromagnetic theory</a>, and more recently <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stephen_Hawking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stephen Hawking (page does not exist)">Stephen Hawking</a>, who has advanced major theories in the fields of <a href="/wiki/Cosmology" title="Cosmology">cosmology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quantum_gravity" title="Quantum gravity">quantum gravity</a> and the investigation of <a href="/wiki/Black_holes" title="Black holes" class="mw-redirect">black holes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[235]</a></sup> Major scientific discoveries from the 18th century include <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen">hydrogen</a> by <a href="/wiki/Henry_Cavendish" title="Henry Cavendish">Henry Cavendish</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[236]</a></sup> from the 20th century <a href="/wiki/Penicillin" title="Penicillin">penicillin</a> by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Fleming" title="Alexander Fleming">Alexander Fleming</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[237]</a></sup> and the structure of <a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Francis_Crick" title="Francis Crick">Francis Crick</a> and others.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[238]</a></sup> Major engineering projects and applications by people from the UK in the 18th century include the <a href="/wiki/Steam_locomotive" title="Steam locomotive">steam locomotive</a>, developed by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Trevithick" title="Richard Trevithick">Richard Trevithick</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Vivian" title="Andrew Vivian">Andrew Vivian</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[239]</a></sup> from the 19th century the <a href="/wiki/Electric_motor" title="Electric motor">electric motor</a> by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Faraday" title="Michael Faraday">Michael Faraday</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Incandescent_light_bulb" title="Incandescent light bulb">incandescent light bulb</a> by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Swan" title="Joseph Swan">Joseph Swan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[240]</a></sup> and the first practical telephone, patented by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Graham_Bell" title="Alexander Graham Bell">Alexander Graham Bell</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[241]</a></sup> and in the 20th century the world's first working television system by <a href="/wiki/John_Logie_Baird" title="John Logie Baird">John Logie Baird</a> and others,<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[242]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Jet_engine" title="Jet engine">jet engine</a> by <a href="/wiki/Frank_Whittle" title="Frank Whittle">Frank Whittle</a>, the basis of the modern computer by <a href="/wiki/Alan_Turing" title="Alan Turing">Alan Turing</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Web" title="World Wide Web">World Wide Web</a> by <a href="/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee" title="Tim Berners-Lee">Tim Berners-Lee</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[243]</a></sup> Scientific research and development remains important in British universities, with many establishing <a href="/wiki/Science_park" title="Science park">science parks</a> to facilitate production and co-operation with industry.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[244]</a></sup> Between 2004 and 2008 the UK produced 7% of the world's scientific research papers and had an 8% share of scientific citations, the third and second highest in the world (after the United States and China, and the United States, respectively).<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[245]</a></sup> Scientific journals produced in the UK include <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/BMJ" title="BMJ">British Medical Journal</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lancet" title="The Lancet">The Lancet</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[246]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Heathrow_T5.jpg" title="File:Heathrow T5.jpg">File:Heathrow T5.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=London_Heathrow_Terminal_5&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="London Heathrow Terminal 5 (page does not exist)">Heathrow Terminal 5 building</a>. <a href="/wiki/London_Heathrow_Airport" title="London Heathrow Airport">London Heathrow Airport</a> has the <a href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_international_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by international passenger traffic">most international passenger traffic</a> of any airport in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc1_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc1-257">[247]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-airport_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-airport-258">[248]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>A radial road network totals <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of main roads, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of motorways and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of paved roads.<sup id="cite_ref-factbook_109-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-109">[101]</a></sup> In 2009 there were a total of 34&#160;million licensed vehicles in Great Britain.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[249]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK has a railway network of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Great_Britain" title="Rail transport in Great Britain">Great Britain</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Ireland_Railways&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Ireland Railways (page does not exist)">Northern Ireland</a>. Railways in Northern Ireland are operated by <a href="/wiki/NI_Railways" title="NI Railways">NI Railways</a>, a subsidiary of state-owned <a href="/wiki/Translink_(Northern_Ireland)" title="Translink (Northern Ireland)">Translink</a>.  In Great Britain, the <a href="/wiki/British_Rail" title="British Rail">British Rail</a> network was privatised between 1994 and 1997. <a href="/wiki/Network_Rail" title="Network Rail">Network Rail</a> owns and manages most of the fixed assets (tracks, signals etc.). About 20 privately owned <a href="/wiki/Train_Operating_Companies" title="Train Operating Companies" class="mw-redirect">Train Operating Companies</a> (including state owned <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Coast_(train_operating_company)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Coast (train operating company) (page does not exist)">East Coast</a>), operate passenger trains and carry over 18,000 passenger trains daily. There are also some 1,000 freight trains in daily operation.<sup id="cite_ref-factbook_109-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-109">[101]</a></sup> The UK government is to spend £30 billion on a new high-speed railway line, <a href="/w/index.php?title=HS2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="HS2 (page does not exist)">HS2</a>, to be operational by 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[250]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Crossrail" title="Crossrail">Crossrail</a>, under construction in London, Is Europe's largest construction project with a £15 billion projected cost.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[251]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[252]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the year from October 2009 to September 2010 UK airports handled a total of 211.4&#160;million passengers.<sup id="cite_ref-caastats_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-caastats-263">[253]</a></sup> In that period the three largest airports were <a href="/wiki/London_Heathrow_Airport" title="London Heathrow Airport">London Heathrow Airport</a> (65.6&#160;million passengers), <a href="/wiki/Gatwick_Airport" title="Gatwick Airport">Gatwick Airport</a> (31.5&#160;million passengers) and <a href="/wiki/London_Stansted_Airport" title="London Stansted Airport">London Stansted Airport</a> (18.9&#160;million passengers).<sup id="cite_ref-caastats_263-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-caastats-263">[253]</a></sup> London Heathrow Airport, located <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> west of the capital, has the most international passenger traffic of any airport in the world<sup id="cite_ref-bbc1_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc1-257">[247]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-airport_258-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-airport-258">[248]</a></sup> and is the hub for the UK flag carrier <a href="/wiki/British_Airways" title="British Airways">British Airways</a>, as well as for <a href="/w/index.php?title=BMI_(airline)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BMI (airline) (page does not exist)">BMI</a> and <a href="/wiki/Virgin_Atlantic" title="Virgin Atlantic">Virgin Atlantic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[254]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg" title="File:Oil platform in the North SeaPros.jpg">File:Oil platform in the North SeaPros.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An oil platform in the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 2006, the UK was the world's ninth-largest consumer of energy and the 15th largest producer.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[255]</a></sup> The UK is home to a number of large energy companies, including two of the six oil and gas "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Supermajor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Supermajor (page does not exist)">supermajors</a>"&#160;– <a href="/w/index.php?title=BP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BP (page does not exist)">BP</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Dutch_Shell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Dutch Shell (page does not exist)">Royal Dutch Shell</a>&#160;– and <a href="/wiki/BG_Group" title="BG Group">BG Group</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[256]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[257]</a></sup> In 2011, 40% of the UK's electricity was produced by gas, 30% by coal, 19% by nuclear power and 4.2% by wind, hydro, biofuels and wastes.<sup id="cite_ref-world-nuclear.org_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world-nuclear.org-268">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, the UK produced 1.5&#160;million barrels per day (bbl/d) of oil and consumed 1.7&#160;million bbl/d.<sup id="cite_ref-eiaoil_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoil-269">[259]</a></sup> Production is now in decline and the UK has been a net importer of oil since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-eiaoil_269-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoil-269">[259]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a> the UK had around 3.1&#160;billion barrels of proven <a href="/wiki/North_Sea_oil" title="North Sea oil">crude oil reserves</a>, the largest of any EU member state.<sup id="cite_ref-eiaoil_269-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoil-269">[259]</a></sup> In 2009, 66.5% of the UK's oil supply was imported.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[260]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, the UK was the 13th largest producer of natural gas in the world and the largest producer in the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-eiagas_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eiagas-271">[261]</a></sup> Production is now in decline and the UK has been a net importer of natural gas since 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-eiagas_271-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eiagas-271">[261]</a></sup> In 2009, half of British gas was supplied from imports and this is expected to increase to at least 75% by 2015, as domestic reserves are depleted.<sup id="cite_ref-world-nuclear.org_268-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world-nuclear.org-268">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p>Coal production played a key role in the UK economy in the 19th and 20th centuries. In the mid-1970s, 130 million tonnes of coal was being produced annually, not falling below 100 million tonnes until the early 1980s. During the 1980s and 1990s the industry was scaled back considerably. In 2011, the UK produced 18.3 million tonnes of coal.<sup id="cite_ref-eiaoverview_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoverview-272">[262]</a></sup> In 2005 it had proven recoverable coal reserves of 171&#160;million tons.<sup id="cite_ref-eiaoverview_272-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoverview-272">[262]</a></sup> The UK <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coal_Authority&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coal Authority (page does not exist)">Coal Authority</a> has stated there is a potential to produce between 7&#160;billion tonnes and 16&#160;billion tonnes of coal through <a href="/w/index.php?title=Underground_coal_gasification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Underground coal gasification (page does not exist)">underground coal gasification (UCG)</a> or '<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fraking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fraking (page does not exist)">fraking</a>',<sup id="cite_ref-Coal_2_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coal_2-273">[263]</a></sup> and that, based on current UK coal consumption, such reserves could last between 200 and 400 years.<sup id="cite_ref-Coal_3_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coal_3-274">[264]</a></sup> However, environmental and social concerns have been raised over chemicals getting into the water table and minor earthquakes damaging homes.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[265]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[266]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the late 1990s, nuclear power plants contributed around 25% of total annual electricity generation in the UK, but this has gradually declined as old plants have been shut down and ageing-related problems affect plant availability. In 2012, the UK had 16 reactors normally generating about 19% of its electricity. All but one of the reactors will be retired by 2023. Unlike Germany and Japan, the UK intends to build a new generation of nuclear plants from about 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-world-nuclear.org_268-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-world-nuclear.org-268">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_dmy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use dmy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use dmy dates</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
