<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Census_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Census in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">census</a> is taken simultaneously in all parts of the UK every ten years.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[267]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a> is responsible for collecting data for England and Wales, the <a href="/wiki/General_Register_Office_for_Scotland" title="General Register Office for Scotland">General Register Office for Scotland</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Ireland_Statistics_and_Research_Agency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency (page does not exist)">Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency</a> each being responsible for censuses in their respective countries.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[268]</a></sup> In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom_Census_2011&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Kingdom Census 2011 (page does not exist)">2011 census</a> the total population of the United Kingdom was 63,181,775.<sup id="cite_ref-2011census_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011census-279">[269]</a></sup> It is the third largest in the European Union, the fifth largest in the Commonwealth and the twenty-first largest in the world. 2010 was the third successive year in which natural change contributed more to population growth than net long-term international migration.<sup id="cite_ref-pop2010_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pop2010-280">[270]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pop2010_280-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pop2010-280">[270]</a></sup> Between 2001 and 2011 the population increased by an average annual rate of approximately 0.7 per cent.<sup id="cite_ref-2011census_279-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011census-279">[269]</a></sup> This compares to 0.3 per cent per year in the period 1991 to 2001 and 0.2 per cent in the decade 1981 to 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-pop2010_280-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pop2010-280">[270]</a></sup> The 2011 census also confirmed that the proportion of the population aged 0–14 has nearly halved (31 per cent in 1911 compared to 18 in 2011) and the proportion of older people aged 65 and over has more than trebled (from 5 to 16 per cent).<sup id="cite_ref-2011census_279-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011census-279">[269]</a></sup> It has been estimated that the number of people aged 100 or over will rise steeply to reach over 626,000 by 2080.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[271]</a></sup>
</p><p>England's population in 2011 was found to be 53 million.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_UK_censuses_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_UK_censuses-282">[272]</a></sup> It is one of the most densely populated countries in the world, with 383&#160;people resident per square kilometre in mid-2003,<sup id="cite_ref-2003density_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2003density-283">[273]</a></sup> with a particular concentration in London and the south-east.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[274]</a></sup> The 2011 census put Scotland's population at 5.3 million,<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[275]</a></sup> Wales at 3.06 million and Northern Ireland at 1.81 million.<sup id="cite_ref-2011_UK_censuses_282-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011_UK_censuses-282">[272]</a></sup> In percentage terms England has had the fastest growing population of any country of the UK in the period from 2001 to 2011, with an increase of 7.9%.
</p><p>In 2009 the average <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> (TFR) across the UK was 1.94 children per woman.<sup id="cite_ref-Fertility2008_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fertility2008-286">[276]</a></sup> While a rising birth rate is contributing to current population growth, it remains considerably below the 'baby boom' peak of 2.95 children per woman in 1964,<sup id="cite_ref-Boseley_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boseley-287">[277]</a></sup> below the replacement rate of 2.1, but higher than the 2001 record low of 1.63.<sup id="cite_ref-Fertility2008_286-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fertility2008-286">[276]</a></sup> In 2010, Scotland had the lowest TFR at only 1.75, followed by Wales at 1.98, England at 2.00, and Northern Ireland at 2.06.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[278]</a></sup> In 2011, 47.3% of births in the UK were to unmarried women.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[279]</a></sup> A government figure estimated that there are 3.6 million homosexual people in Britain comprising 6 per cent of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[280]</a></sup>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_Urban_Areas_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Largest Urban Areas of the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Template:Largest Urban Areas of the United Kingdom</a>
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable" style="line-height:0.9em; border:1px black; float:right; margin-left:1em">

<tr>
<th style="width:140px;"> <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">Ethnic group</a> </th>

<th>&#160;% of total*
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_British&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White British (page does not exist)">White British</a> </td>
<td> 50,366,497 </td>
<td> 86%
</td></tr>

<td> 1.0%
</td></tr>
<tr>

<td> 0.8%
</td></tr>
<tr>

</td></tr>

<td> 0.4%
</td></tr>

<td> 247,403 </td>
<td> 0.4%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Other_ethnic_group_(United_Kingdom_Census)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Other ethnic group (United Kingdom Census) (page does not exist)">Other</a> </td>
<td> 230,615 </td>
<td> 0.4%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Black_British&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Black British (page does not exist)">Black (others)</a> </td>
<td> 97,585 </td>
<td> 0.2%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="3"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Smaller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Smaller (page does not exist)">Template:Smaller</a>
</td></tr></table>
<p>Historically, indigenous British people were thought to be <a href="/w/index.php?title=Genetic_history_of_the_British_Isles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Genetic history of the British Isles (page does not exist)">descended from the various ethnic groups</a> that settled there before the 11th century: the <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a>, Romans, Anglo-Saxons, Norse and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Normans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Normans (page does not exist)">Normans</a>. <a href="/wiki/Welsh_people" title="Welsh people">Welsh people</a> could be the oldest ethnic group in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[281]</a></sup> Recent genetic studies have shown that more than 50 per cent of England's gene pool contains <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> Y chromosomes,<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[282]</a></sup> though other recent genetic analysis indicates that "about 75 per cent of the traceable ancestors of the modern British population had arrived in the British isles by about 6,200 years ago, at the start of the British Neolithic or Stone Age", and that the British broadly share a common ancestry with the <a href="/wiki/Basque_people" title="Basque people">Basque people</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[283]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[284]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Henderson_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Henderson-295">[285]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK has a history of small-scale non-white immigration, with <a href="/wiki/Liverpool" title="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> having the oldest Black population in the country dating back to at least the 1730s,<sup id="cite_ref-Costello_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Costello-296">[286]</a></sup> and the oldest <a href="/wiki/British_Chinese" title="British Chinese">Chinese</a> community in Europe, dating to the arrival of Chinese seamen in the 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Chinese_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chinese-297">[287]</a></sup> In 1950 there were probably fewer than 20,000 non-white residents in Britain, almost all born overseas.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[288]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1948 substantial immigration from Africa, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caribbean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caribbean (page does not exist)">Caribbean</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Asia (page does not exist)">South Asia</a> has been a legacy of ties forged by the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>. Migration from new EU member states in <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and Eastern Europe since 2004 has resulted in growth in these population groups but, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, the trend is reversing and many of these migrants are returning home, leaving the size of these groups unknown.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[289]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, 92.1% of the population identified themselves as White, leaving 7.9%<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[290]</a></sup> of the UK population identifying themselves as  of mixed <a href="/wiki/Minority_group" title="Minority group">ethnic minority</a>.
</p><p>Ethnic diversity varies significantly across the UK. 30.4% of London's population<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[291]</a></sup> and 37.4% of <a href="/wiki/Leicester" title="Leicester">Leicester</a>'s<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[292]</a></sup> was estimated to be non-white <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, whereas less than 5% of the populations of <a href="/wiki/North_East_England" title="North East England">North East England</a>, Wales and the <a href="/wiki/South_West_England" title="South West England">South West</a> were from ethnic minorities according to the 2001 census.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[293]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, 26.5% of primary and 22.2% of secondary pupils at <a href="/wiki/State_school" title="State school">state schools</a> in England were members of an ethnic minority.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[294]</a></sup>
</p><p>The non-white British population of England and Wales increased by 38% from 6.6 million in 2001 to 9.1 million in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[295]</a></sup> The fastest-growing group was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mixed_(United_Kingdom_ethnicity_category)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mixed (United Kingdom ethnicity category) (page does not exist)">mixed-ethnicity</a> population, which doubled from 672,000 in 2001 to 986,600 in 2009. Also in the same period, a decrease of 36,000 white British people was recorded.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[296]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Anglospeak.svg" title="File:Anglospeak.svg">File:Anglospeak.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_world" title="English-speaking world" class="mw-redirect">English-speaking world</a>. Countries in dark blue have a majority of native speakers; countries where English is an official but not a majority language are shaded in light blue. English is one of the official languages <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union" title="Languages of the European Union">of the European Union</a><sup id="cite_ref-EUlang_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUlang-307">[297]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Official_languages_of_the_United_Nations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Official languages of the United Nations (page does not exist)">the United Nations</a><sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[298]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The UK's <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> is <a href="/wiki/British_English" title="British English">English</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-direct.gov.uk_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-direct.gov.uk-4">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-thecommonwealth.org_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thecommonwealth.org-5">[3]</a></sup> It is estimated that 95% of the UK's population are <a href="/wiki/Monolingual" title="Monolingual" class="mw-redirect">monolingual</a> English speakers.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_languages_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_languages-309">[299]</a></sup> 5.5% of the population are estimated to speak languages brought to the UK as a result of relatively recent immigration.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_languages_309-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_languages-309">[299]</a></sup> South Asian languages, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bengali_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bengali language (page does not exist)">Bengali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">Punjabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>, are the largest grouping and are spoken by 2.7% of the UK population.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_languages_309-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_languages-309">[299]</a></sup> According to the 2011 census, <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a> has become the second largest language spoken in England and has 546,000 speakers.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[300]</a></sup>
</p><p>Four <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">Celtic languages</a> are spoken in the UK: <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Irish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irish language (page does not exist)">Irish</a>; <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">Scottish Gaelic</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Cornish_language" title="Cornish language">Cornish</a>. The first three are recognised as regional or minority languages, subject to specific measures of protection and promotion under relevant <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European law</a>. Cornish, although recognised, is not specifically protected. In the 2001 Census over a fifth (21%) of the population of Wales said they could speak Welsh,<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[301]</a></sup> an increase from the 1991 Census (18%).<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[302]</a></sup> In addition it is estimated that about 200,000 Welsh speakers live in England.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[303]</a></sup> In the same census in Northern Ireland 167,487 people (10.4%) stated that they had "some knowledge of Irish" (see <a href="/wiki/Irish_language_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Irish language in Northern Ireland">Irish language in Northern Ireland</a>), almost exclusively in the <a href="/wiki/Irish_nationalism" title="Irish nationalism">nationalist</a> (mainly Catholic) population. Over 92,000 people in Scotland (just under 2% of the population) had some Gaelic language ability, including 72% of those living in the <a href="/wiki/Outer_Hebrides" title="Outer Hebrides">Outer Hebrides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[304]</a></sup> The number of schoolchildren being taught through Welsh, Scottish Gaelic and Irish is increasing.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[305]</a></sup> Among emigrant-descended populations some Scottish Gaelic is still <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Gaelic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canadian Gaelic (page does not exist)">spoken in Canada</a> (principally <a href="/wiki/Nova_Scotia" title="Nova Scotia">Nova Scotia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cape_Breton_Island" title="Cape Breton Island">Cape Breton Island</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-Edwards2010_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Edwards2010-316">[306]</a></sup> and Welsh in <a href="/wiki/Patagonia" title="Patagonia">Patagonia</a>, Argentina.<sup id="cite_ref-Koch2006_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Koch2006-317">[307]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">Scots</a>, a language descended from early northern <a href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">Middle English</a>, has limited <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">recognition</a> alongside its regional variant, <a href="/wiki/Ulster_Scots_dialects" title="Ulster Scots dialects">Ulster Scots</a> in Northern Ireland, without specific commitments to protection and promotion.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[308]</a></sup>
</p><p>It is compulsory for pupils to study a second language up to the age of 14 in England,<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[309]</a></sup> and up to age 16 in Scotland. French and German are the two most commonly taught second languages in England and Scotland. All pupils in Wales are taught Welsh as a second language up to age 16, or are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Welsh_medium_education&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Welsh medium education (page does not exist)">taught in Welsh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[310]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey,_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg" title="File:West Side of Westminster Abbey, London - geograph.org.uk - 1406999.jpg">File:West Side of Westminster Abbey, London - geograph.org.uk - 1406999.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a> is used for the <a href="/wiki/Coronation" title="Coronation">coronation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">British monarchs</a></div></div></div>
<p>Forms of Christianity have dominated religious life in what is now the United Kingdom for over 1,400 years.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[311]</a></sup> Although a majority of citizens still identify with Christianity in many surveys, regular church attendance has fallen dramatically since the middle of the 20th century,<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[312]</a></sup> while immigration and demographic change have contributed to the growth of other faiths, most notably Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[313]</a></sup> This has led some commentators to variously describe the UK as a multi-faith,<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[314]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secularised</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[315]</a></sup> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Post-Christian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Post-Christian (page does not exist)">post-Christian</a> society.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[316]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 2001 census 71.6% of all respondents indicated that they were Christians, with the next largest faiths (by number of adherents) being Islam (2.8%), <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> (1.0%), <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a> (0.6%), Judaism (0.5%), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhism (page does not exist)">Buddhism</a> (0.3%) and all other religions (0.3%).<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[317]</a></sup> 15% of respondents stated that they had <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">no religion</a>, with a further 7% not stating a religious preference.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[318]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Tearfund" title="Tearfund">Tearfund</a> survey in 2007 showed only one in ten Britons actually attend church weekly.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[319]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a> is the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">established church</a> in England.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[320]</a></sup> It retains a <a href="/wiki/Lords_Spiritual" title="Lords Spiritual">representation</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">UK Parliament</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">British monarch</a> is its <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Governor_of_the_Church_of_England" title="Supreme Governor of the Church of England">Supreme Governor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[321]</a></sup> In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Religion_in_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Religion in Scotland (page does not exist)">Scotland</a> the <a href="/wiki/Presbyterianism" title="Presbyterianism">Presbyterian</a> <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Scotland" title="Church of Scotland">Church of Scotland</a> is recognised as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National church (page does not exist)">national church</a>. It is not <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">subject to state control</a>, and the British monarch is an ordinary member, required to swear an oath to "maintain and preserve the Protestant Religion and Presbyterian Church Government" upon his or her accession.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[322]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[323]</a></sup> The (Anglican) <a href="/wiki/Church_in_Wales" title="Church in Wales">Church in Wales</a> was disestablished in 1920 and, as the (Anglican) <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Ireland" title="Church of Ireland">Church of Ireland</a> was disestablished in 1870 before the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Partition_of_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Partition of Ireland (page does not exist)">partition of Ireland</a>, there is no established church in Northern Ireland.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[324]</a></sup> Although there are no UK-wide data in the 2001 census on adherence to individual Christian denominations, it has been estimated that 62% of Christians are Anglican, 13.5% <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic</a>, 6% <a href="/wiki/Presbyterian" title="Presbyterian" class="mw-redirect">Presbyterian</a>, 3.4% <a href="/wiki/Methodist" title="Methodist" class="mw-redirect">Methodist</a> with small numbers of other Protestant denominations such as <a href="/wiki/Open_Brethren" title="Open Brethren">Open Brethren</a>, and  <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a> churches.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[325]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Migration">Migration</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png" title="File:United Kingdom foreign born population by country of birth.png">File:United Kingdom foreign born population by country of birth.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Estimated foreign-born population by country of birth, April 2007&#160;– March 2008</div></div></div>
<p>The United Kingdom has experienced successive waves of migration. The <a href="/wiki/Great_Famine_(Ireland)" title="Great Famine (Ireland)">Great Famine</a> in Ireland resulted in perhaps a million people migrating to the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[326]</a></sup> Over 120,000 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Polish_Armed_Forces_in_the_West&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Polish Armed Forces in the West (page does not exist)">Polish</a> veterans settled in Britain after World War II, unable to return home.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[327]</a></sup> After World War II, there was significant immigration from the colonies and newly independent former colonies, partly as a legacy of empire and partly driven by labour shortages. Many of these migrants came from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caribbean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caribbean (page does not exist)">Caribbean</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_subcontinent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian subcontinent (page does not exist)">Indian subcontinent</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[328]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Asian" title="British Asian">British Asian</a> population has increased from 2.2 million in 2001 to over 4.2 million in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[329]</a></sup>
</p><p>One of the more recent trends in migration has been the arrival of workers from the new EU member states in Eastern Europe. In 2010, there were 7.0 million foreign-born residents in the UK, corresponding to 11.3% of the total population. Of these, 4.76 million (7.7%) were born outside the EU and 2.24 million (3.6%) were born in another EU Member State.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[330]</a></sup> The proportion of foreign-born people in the UK remains slightly below that of many other European countries.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[331]</a></sup> However, immigration is now contributing to a rising population<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[332]</a></sup> with arrivals and UK-born children of migrants accounting for about half of the population increase between 1991 and 2001. Analysis of <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a> (ONS) data shows that a net total of 2.3&#160;million migrants moved to the UK in the 15 years from 1991 to 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[333]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[334]</a></sup> In 2008 it was predicted that migration would add 7&#160;million to the UK population by 2031,<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[335]</a></sup> though these figures are disputed.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[336]</a></sup> The ONS reported that net migration rose from 2009 to 2010 by 21 per cent to 239,000.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[337]</a></sup> In 2011 the net increase was 251,000: immigration was 589,000, while the number of people emigrating (for more than 12 months) was 338,000.<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Statistics_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Statistics-348">[338]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[339]</a></sup>
</p><p>195,046 foreign nationals became British citizens in 2010,<sup id="cite_ref-home_office_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-home_office-350">[340]</a></sup> compared to 54,902 in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-home_office_350-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-home_office-350">[340]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[341]</a></sup> A record 241,192 people were granted permanent settlement rights in 2010, of whom 51 per cent were from Asia and 27 per cent from Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[342]</a></sup> 25.5 per cent of babies born in England and Wales in 2011 were born to mothers born outside the UK, according to official statistics released in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[343]</a></sup>
</p><p>Citizens of the European Union, including those of the UK, have the right to live and work in any EU member state.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[344]</a></sup> The UK applied temporary restrictions to citizens of Romania and Bulgaria, which joined the EU in January 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[345]</a></sup> Research conducted by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Migration_Policy_Institute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Migration Policy Institute (page does not exist)">Migration Policy Institute</a> for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Equality_and_Human_Rights_Commission&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Equality and Human Rights Commission (page does not exist)">Equality and Human Rights Commission</a> suggests that, between May 2004 and September 2009, 1.5&#160;million workers migrated from the new EU member states to the UK, two-thirds of them Polish, but that many subsequently returned home, resulting in a net increase in the number of nationals of the new member states in the UK of some 700,000 over that period.<sup id="cite_ref-MPI_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MPI-356">[346]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[347]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Late-2000s_recession&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Late-2000s recession (page does not exist)">late-2000s recession</a> in the UK reduced the economic incentive for Poles to migrate to the UK,<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[348]</a></sup> the migration becoming temporary and circular.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[349]</a></sup> In 2009, for the first time since enlargement, more nationals of the eight central and eastern European states that had joined the EU in 2004 left the UK than arrived.<sup id="cite_ref-A8_leaving_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A8_leaving-360">[350]</a></sup> In 2011, citizens of the new EU member states made up 13% of the immigrants entering the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Migration_Statistics_348-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Migration_Statistics-348">[338]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:British_expats_countrymap.svg" title="File:British expats countrymap.svg">File:British expats countrymap.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Estimated number of British citizens living overseas by country, 2006</div></div></div>
<p>The UK government has introduced a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Points-based_immigration_system_(United_Kingdom)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Points-based immigration system (United Kingdom) (page does not exist)">points-based immigration system</a> for immigration from outside the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">European Economic Area</a> to replace former schemes, including the Scottish Government's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fresh_Talent_Initiative&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fresh Talent Initiative (page does not exist)">Fresh Talent Initiative</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[351]</a></sup> In June 2010 the UK government introduced a temporary limit of 24,000 on immigration from outside the EU, aiming to discourage applications before a permanent cap was imposed in April 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[352]</a></sup> The cap has caused tension within the coalition: business secretary <a href="/wiki/Vince_Cable" title="Vince Cable">Vince Cable</a> has argued that it is harming British businesses.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[353]</a></sup>
</p><p>Emigration was an important feature of British society in the 19th century. Between 1815 and 1930 around 11.4&#160;million people emigrated from Britain and 7.3&#160;million from Ireland. Estimates show that by the end of the 20th century some 300&#160;million people of British and Irish descent were permanently settled around the globe.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[354]</a></sup> Today, at least 5.5&#160;million UK-born people live abroad,<sup id="cite_ref-BritsAbroad_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BritsAbroad-365">[355]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[356]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[357]</a></sup> mainly in Australia, Spain, the United States and Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-BritsAbroad_365-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BritsAbroad-365">[355]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[358]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg" title="File:KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg">File:KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/King%27s_College,_Cambridge" title="King's College, Cambridge">King's College</a>, part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Cambridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Cambridge (page does not exist)">University of Cambridge</a>, which was founded in 1209</div></div></div>
<p>Education in the United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved</a> matter, with each country having a separate education system.
</p><p>Whilst <a href="/wiki/Education_in_England" title="Education in England">education in England</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Education" title="Secretary of State for Education">Secretary of State for Education</a>, the day-to-day administration and funding of state schools is the responsibility of <a href="/wiki/Local_education_authority" title="Local education authority">local authorities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[359]</a></sup> Universally free of charge state education was introduced piecemeal between 1870 and 1944.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[360]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[361]</a></sup> Education is now mandatory from ages five to sixteen (15 if born in late July or August). In 2011, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trends_in_International_Mathematics_and_Science_Study&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study (page does not exist)">Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study</a> (TIMSS) rated 13–14-year-old pupils in England and Wales 10th in the world for maths and 9th for science.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[362]</a></sup> The majority of children are educated in state-sector schools, a small proportion of which select on the grounds of academic ability. Two of the top ten performing schools in terms of <a href="/wiki/GCSE" title="GCSE" class="mw-redirect">GCSE</a> results in 2006 were state-run <a href="/wiki/Grammar_school" title="Grammar school">grammar schools</a>. Over half of students at the leading universities of Cambridge and Oxford had attended state schools.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[363]</a></sup> Despite a fall in actual numbers the proportion of children in England attending private schools has risen to over 7%.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[364]</a></sup> In 2010, more than 45% of places at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford">University of Oxford</a> and 40% at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Cambridge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Cambridge (page does not exist)">University of Cambridge</a> were taken by students from private schools, even though they educate just 7% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[365]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Universities_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Universities of England (page does not exist)">universities of England</a> are among some of the top universities in the world; the University of Cambridge, the University of Oxford, the <a href="/wiki/University_College_London" title="University College London">University College London</a> and <a href="/wiki/Imperial_College_London" title="Imperial College London">Imperial College London</a> are all ranked in the global top 10 in the 2010 <a href="/w/index.php?title=QS_World_University_Rankings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="QS World University Rankings (page does not exist)">QS World University Rankings</a>, with Cambridge ranked first.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[366]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:QUB.jpg" title="File:QUB.jpg">File:QUB.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Queen%27s_University_Belfast" title="Queen's University Belfast">Queen's University Belfast</a>, built in 1849<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[367]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Education_in_Scotland" title="Education in Scotland">Education in Scotland</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cabinet_Secretary_for_Education_and_Lifelong_Learning&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cabinet Secretary for Education and Lifelong Learning (page does not exist)">Cabinet Secretary for Education and Lifelong Learning</a>, with day-to-day administration and funding of state schools the responsibility of Local Authorities. Two <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_public_bodies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish public bodies (page does not exist)">non-departmental public bodies</a> have key roles in Scottish education. The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Qualifications_Authority" title="Scottish Qualifications Authority">Scottish Qualifications Authority</a> is responsible for the development, accreditation, assessment and certification of qualifications other than degrees which are delivered at secondary schools, <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">post-secondary</a> colleges of <a href="/wiki/Further_education" title="Further education">further education</a> and other centres.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[368]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Learning_and_Teaching_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Learning and Teaching Scotland (page does not exist)">Learning and Teaching Scotland</a> provides advice, resources and staff development to education professionals.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[369]</a></sup> Scotland first legislated for compulsory education in 1496.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[370]</a></sup> The proportion of children in Scotland attending private schools is just over 4%, and it has been rising slowly in recent years.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[371]</a></sup> Scottish students who attend <a href="/wiki/Scottish_universities" title="Scottish universities" class="mw-redirect">Scottish universities</a> pay neither <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tuition_fees&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tuition fees (page does not exist)">tuition fees</a> nor graduate endowment charges, as fees were abolished in 2001 and the graduate endowment scheme was abolished in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[372]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Scotland" title="List of universities in Scotland">universities of Scotland</a> are among some of the top universities in the world; the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Edinburgh (page does not exist)">University of Edinburgh</a>, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Glasgow" title="University of Glasgow">University of Glasgow</a> and the <a href="/wiki/University_of_St_Andrews" title="University of St Andrews">University of St Andrews</a> are all ranked in the global top 100 in the 2012 <a href="/w/index.php?title=QS_World_University_Rankings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="QS World University Rankings (page does not exist)">QS World University Rankings</a>, with Edinburgh ranked 21st.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[373]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Government" title="Welsh Government">Welsh Government</a> has responsibility for <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Wales" title="Education in Wales">education in Wales</a>. A significant number of Welsh students are taught either wholly or largely in the <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh language</a>; lessons in Welsh are compulsory for all until the age of 16.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[374]</a></sup> There are plans to increase the provision of Welsh-medium schools as part of the policy of creating a fully bilingual Wales.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Education_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Education in Northern Ireland">Education in Northern Ireland</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Department_of_Education_(Northern_Ireland)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Department of Education (Northern Ireland) (page does not exist)">Minister of Education</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Department_for_Employment_and_Learning&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Department for Employment and Learning (page does not exist)">Minister for Employment and Learning</a>, although responsibility at a local level is administered by five education and library boards covering different geographical areas. The <a href="/wiki/Council_for_the_Curriculum,_Examinations_%26_Assessment" title="Council for the Curriculum, Examinations &amp; Assessment">Council for the Curriculum, Examinations &amp; Assessment</a> (CCEA) is the body responsible for advising the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">government</a> on what should be taught in Northern Ireland's schools, monitoring standards and awarding qualifications.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[375]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">Healthcare</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Royal_Aberdeen_Children%27s_Hospital.jpg" title="File:Royal Aberdeen Children's Hospital.jpg">File:Royal Aberdeen Children's Hospital.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Aberdeen_Children%27s_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Aberdeen Children's Hospital (page does not exist)">Royal Aberdeen Children's Hospital</a>, an <a href="/w/index.php?title=NHS_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NHS Scotland (page does not exist)">NHS Scotland</a> specialist <a href="/wiki/Children%27s_hospital" title="Children's hospital">children's hospital</a></div></div></div>
<p>Healthcare in the United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved matter</a> and each country has its own system of private and <a href="/wiki/Publicly_funded_health_care" title="Publicly funded health care">publicly funded health care</a>, together with <a href="/wiki/Alternative_medicine" title="Alternative medicine">alternative</a>, holistic and complementary treatments. Public healthcare is provided to all <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_nationality_law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British nationality law (page does not exist)">UK permanent residents</a> and is mostly free at the point of need, being paid for from general taxation. The <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>, in 2000, ranked the provision of healthcare in the United Kingdom as fifteenth best in Europe and eighteenth in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Who2000_386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Who2000-386">[376]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[377]</a></sup>
</p><p>Regulatory bodies are organised on a UK-wide basis such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_Medical_Council&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="General Medical Council (page does not exist)">General Medical Council</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Nursing_and_Midwifery_Council" title="Nursing and Midwifery Council">Nursing and Midwifery Council</a> and non-governmental-based, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_College&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal College (page does not exist)">Royal Colleges</a>. However, political and operational responsibility for healthcare lies with four national <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executives</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Healthcare_in_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Healthcare in England (page does not exist)">healthcare in England</a> is the responsibility of the UK Government; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Healthcare_in_Northern_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Healthcare in Northern Ireland (page does not exist)">healthcare in Northern Ireland</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">Northern Ireland Executive</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Healthcare_in_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Healthcare in Scotland (page does not exist)">healthcare in Scotland</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a>; and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Healthcare_in_Wales&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Healthcare in Wales (page does not exist)">healthcare in Wales</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Welsh_Assembly_Government&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Welsh Assembly Government (page does not exist)">Welsh Assembly Government</a>. Each <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Health_Service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Health Service (page does not exist)">National Health Service</a> has different policies and priorities, resulting in contrasts.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[378]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[379]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1979 expenditure on healthcare has been increased significantly to bring it closer to the European Union average.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[380]</a></sup> The UK spends around 8.4 per cent of its gross domestic product on healthcare, which is 0.5 percentage points below the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (page does not exist)">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> average and about one percentage point below the average of the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[381]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The culture of the United Kingdom has been influenced by many factors including: the nation's island status; its <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="History of the United Kingdom">history</a> as a western liberal democracy and a major power; as well as being a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Political_union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Political union (page does not exist)">political union</a> of four countries with each preserving elements of distinctive traditions, customs and symbolism. As a result of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>, British influence can be observed in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English language (page does not exist)">language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">legal systems</a> of many of its former colonies; including Australia, Canada, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, Ireland, New Zealand, South Africa and the United States. The substantial cultural influence of the United Kingdom has led it to be described as a "cultural superpower."<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[382]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[383]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg" title="File:William Shakespeare Chandos Portrait.jpg">File:William Shakespeare Chandos Portrait.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Chandos_portrait" title="Chandos portrait">Chandos portrait</a>, believed to depict <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a></div></div></div>
<p>'British literature' refers to literature associated with the United Kingdom, the <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">Isle of Man</a> and the Channel Islands. Most British literature is in the English language. In 2005, some 206,000 books were published in the United Kingdom and in 2006 it was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Books_published_per_country_per_year&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Books published per country per year (page does not exist)">largest publisher of books</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Reuters_394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-394">[384]</a></sup>
</p><p>The English playwright and poet <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> is widely regarded as the greatest dramatist of all time,<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[385]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[386]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[387]</a></sup> and his contemporaries <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Marlowe" title="Christopher Marlowe">Christopher Marlowe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ben_Jonson" title="Ben Jonson">Ben Jonson</a> have also been held in continuous high esteem. More recently the playwrights <a href="/wiki/Alan_Ayckbourn" title="Alan Ayckbourn">Alan Ayckbourn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harold_Pinter" title="Harold Pinter">Harold Pinter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Frayn" title="Michael Frayn">Michael Frayn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Stoppard" title="Tom Stoppard">Tom Stoppard</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Edgar_(playwright)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="David Edgar (playwright) (page does not exist)">David Edgar</a> have combined elements of surrealism, realism and radicalism.
</p><p>Notable pre-modern and early-modern English writers include <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer" title="Geoffrey Chaucer">Geoffrey Chaucer</a> (14th century), <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Malory" title="Thomas Malory">Thomas Malory</a> (15th century), <a href="/wiki/Thomas_More" title="Thomas More">Sir Thomas More</a> (16th century), <a href="/wiki/John_Bunyan" title="John Bunyan">John Bunyan</a> (17th century) and <a href="/wiki/John_Milton" title="John Milton">John Milton</a> (17th century). In the 18th century <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Defoe" title="Daniel Defoe">Daniel Defoe</a> (author of <i><a href="/wiki/Robinson_Crusoe" title="Robinson Crusoe">Robinson Crusoe</a></i>) and <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Richardson" title="Samuel Richardson">Samuel Richardson</a> were pioneers of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Modern_novel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Modern novel (page does not exist)">modern novel</a>. In the 19th century there followed further innovation by <a href="/wiki/Jane_Austen" title="Jane Austen">Jane Austen</a>, the gothic novelist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mary_Shelley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mary Shelley (page does not exist)">Mary Shelley</a>, children's writer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lewis_Carroll&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lewis Carroll (page does not exist)">Lewis Carroll</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bront%C3%AB_family" title="Brontë family">Brontë sisters</a>, the social campaigner <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Naturalism_(literature)" title="Naturalism (literature)">naturalist</a> <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Hardy" title="Thomas Hardy">Thomas Hardy</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Realism_(arts)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Realism (arts) (page does not exist)">realist</a> <a href="/wiki/George_Eliot" title="George Eliot">George Eliot</a>, the visionary poet <a href="/wiki/William_Blake" title="William Blake">William Blake</a> and romantic poet <a href="/wiki/William_Wordsworth" title="William Wordsworth">William Wordsworth</a>. 20th-century English writers include science-fiction novelist <a href="/wiki/H._G._Wells" title="H. G. Wells">H. G. Wells</a>; the writers of children's classics <a href="/wiki/Rudyard_Kipling" title="Rudyard Kipling">Rudyard Kipling</a>, <a href="/wiki/A._A._Milne" title="A. A. Milne">A. A. Milne</a> (the creator of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Winnie-the-Pooh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Winnie-the-Pooh (page does not exist)">Winnie-the-Pooh</a>), <a href="/wiki/Roald_Dahl" title="Roald Dahl">Roald Dahl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Enid_Blyton" title="Enid Blyton">Enid Blyton</a>; the controversial <a href="/wiki/D._H._Lawrence" title="D. H. Lawrence">D. H. Lawrence</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Modernism" title="Modernism">modernist</a> <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Woolf" title="Virginia Woolf">Virginia Woolf</a>; the satirist <a href="/wiki/Evelyn_Waugh" title="Evelyn Waugh">Evelyn Waugh</a>; the prophetic novelist <a href="/wiki/George_Orwell" title="George Orwell">George Orwell</a>; the popular novelists <a href="/wiki/W._Somerset_Maugham" title="W. Somerset Maugham">W. Somerset Maugham</a> and <a href="/wiki/Graham_Greene" title="Graham Greene">Graham Greene</a>; the crime writer <a href="/wiki/Agatha_Christie" title="Agatha Christie">Agatha Christie</a> (the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_best-selling_fiction_authors&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of best-selling fiction authors (page does not exist)">best-selling novelist</a> of all time);<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[388]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ian_Fleming" title="Ian Fleming">Ian Fleming</a> (the creator of <a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">James Bond</a>); the poets <a href="/wiki/T.S._Eliot" title="T.S. Eliot" class="mw-redirect">T.S. Eliot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philip_Larkin" title="Philip Larkin">Philip Larkin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ted_Hughes" title="Ted Hughes">Ted Hughes</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Fantasy_literature" title="Fantasy literature">fantasy</a> writers <a href="/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien" title="J. R. R. Tolkien">J. R. R. Tolkien</a>, <a href="/wiki/C._S._Lewis" title="C. S. Lewis">C. S. Lewis</a> and <a href="/wiki/J._K._Rowling" title="J. K. Rowling">J. K. Rowling</a>; the graphic novelist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alan_Moore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alan Moore (page does not exist)">Alan Moore</a>, whose novel <i><a href="/wiki/Watchmen" title="Watchmen">Watchmen</a></i> is often cited by critics as comic’s greatest series and <a href="/wiki/Graphic_novel" title="Graphic novel">graphic novel</a><sup id="cite_ref-IGN_Essential_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IGN_Essential-399">[389]</a></sup> and one of the best-selling graphic novels ever published.<sup id="cite_ref-BleedingCool_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BleedingCool-400">[390]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dickens_by_Watkins_detail.jpg" title="File:Dickens by Watkins detail.jpg">File:Dickens by Watkins detail.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A photograph of <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian era</a> novelist <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Scottish_literature" title="Scottish literature">Scotland's contributions</a> include the detective writer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arthur_Conan_Doyle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arthur Conan Doyle (page does not exist)">Arthur Conan Doyle</a> (the creator of <a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes" title="Sherlock Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a>), romantic literature by <a href="/wiki/Walter_Scott" title="Walter Scott">Sir Walter Scott</a>, children's writer <a href="/wiki/J._M._Barrie" title="J. M. Barrie">J. M. Barrie</a>, the epic adventures of <a href="/wiki/Robert_Louis_Stevenson" title="Robert Louis Stevenson">Robert Louis Stevenson</a> and the celebrated poet <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Burns&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Burns (page does not exist)">Robert Burns</a>. More recently the modernist and nationalist <a href="/wiki/Hugh_MacDiarmid" title="Hugh MacDiarmid">Hugh MacDiarmid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neil_M._Gunn" title="Neil M. Gunn">Neil M. Gunn</a> contributed to the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Renaissance" title="Scottish Renaissance">Scottish Renaissance</a>. A more grim outlook is found in <a href="/wiki/Ian_Rankin" title="Ian Rankin">Ian Rankin</a>'s stories and the psychological horror-comedy of <a href="/wiki/Iain_Banks" title="Iain Banks">Iain Banks</a>. Scotland's capital, Edinburgh, was UNESCO's first worldwide <a href="/w/index.php?title=City_of_Literature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="City of Literature (page does not exist)">City of Literature</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[391]</a></sup>
</p><p>Britain's oldest known poem, <i><a href="/wiki/Y_Gododdin" title="Y Gododdin">Y Gododdin</a></i>, was composed in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hen_Ogledd&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hen Ogledd (page does not exist)">Yr Hen Ogledd</a></i> (<i>The Old North</i>), most likely in the late 6th century. It was written in <a href="/wiki/Cumbric_language" title="Cumbric language">Cumbric</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_Welsh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old Welsh (page does not exist)">Old Welsh</a> and contains the earliest known reference to <a href="/wiki/King_Arthur" title="King Arthur">King Arthur</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[392]</a></sup> From around the seventh century, the connection between Wales and the Old North was lost, and the focus of Welsh-language culture shifted to Wales, where Arthurian legend was further developed by <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth" title="Geoffrey of Monmouth">Geoffrey of Monmouth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[393]</a></sup> Wales's most celebrated medieval poet, <a href="/wiki/Dafydd_ap_Gwilym" title="Dafydd ap Gwilym">Dafydd ap Gwilym</a> (<i>fl.</i>1320–1370), composed poetry on themes including nature, religion and especially love. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest European poets of his age.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[394]</a></sup> Until the late 19th century the majority of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Welsh_literature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Welsh literature (page does not exist)">Welsh literature</a> was in Welsh and much of the prose was religious in character. <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Owen" title="Daniel Owen">Daniel Owen</a> is credited as the first Welsh-language novelist, publishing <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rhys_Lewis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rhys Lewis (page does not exist)">Rhys Lewis</a></i> in 1885. The best-known of the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Welsh_poetry" title="Anglo-Welsh poetry" class="mw-redirect">Anglo-Welsh poets</a> are both Thomases. <a href="/wiki/Dylan_Thomas" title="Dylan Thomas">Dylan Thomas</a> became famous on both sides of the Atlantic in the mid-20th century. He is remembered for his poetry&#160;– his "<a href="/wiki/Do_not_go_gentle_into_that_good_night" title="Do not go gentle into that good night">Do not go gentle into that good night</a>; Rage, rage against the dying of the light." is one of the most quoted couplets of English language verse&#160;– and for his 'play for voices', <i><a href="/wiki/Under_Milk_Wood" title="Under Milk Wood">Under Milk Wood</a></i>. Influential <a href="/wiki/Church_in_Wales" title="Church in Wales">Church in Wales</a> 'poet-priest' and <a href="/wiki/Welsh_nationalism" title="Welsh nationalism">Welsh nationalist</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=R._S._Thomas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="R. S. Thomas (page does not exist)">R. S. Thomas</a>, was nominated for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobel_Prize_in_Literature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobel Prize in Literature (page does not exist)">Nobel Prize in Literature</a> in 1996. Leading Welsh novelists of the twentieth century include <a href="/wiki/Richard_Llewellyn" title="Richard Llewellyn">Richard Llewellyn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kate_Roberts_(author)" title="Kate Roberts (author)">Kate Roberts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[395]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[396]</a></sup>
</p><p>Authors of other nationalities, particularly from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Commonwealth of Nations (page does not exist)">Commonwealth</a> countries, the Republic of Ireland and the United States, have lived and worked in the UK. Significant examples through the centuries include <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Swift" title="Jonathan Swift">Jonathan Swift</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Wilde" title="Oscar Wilde">Oscar Wilde</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bram_Stoker" title="Bram Stoker">Bram Stoker</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw" title="George Bernard Shaw">George Bernard Shaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Conrad" title="Joseph Conrad">Joseph Conrad</a>, <a href="/wiki/T.S._Eliot" title="T.S. Eliot" class="mw-redirect">T.S. Eliot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ezra_Pound" title="Ezra Pound">Ezra Pound</a> and more recently British authors born abroad such as <a href="/wiki/Kazuo_Ishiguro" title="Kazuo Ishiguro">Kazuo Ishiguro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Salman_Rushdie" title="Salman Rushdie">Sir Salman Rushdie</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[397]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[398]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Fabs.JPG" title="File:The Fabs.JPG">File:The Fabs.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> are one of the most commercially successful and critically acclaimed bands in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_classical_music_traditions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of classical music traditions (page does not exist)">history of music</a>, selling over a billion records internationally.<sup id="cite_ref-Beatles_sales_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beatles_sales-409">[399]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-McCartney_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCartney-410">[400]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Guinness_411-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guinness-411">[401]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Various styles of music are popular in the UK from the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a> of <a href="/wiki/Folk_music_of_England" title="Folk music of England">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Wales#Folk_music" title="Music of Wales">Wales</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Folk_music_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Folk music of Scotland (page does not exist)">Scotland</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Folk_music_of_Northern_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Folk music of Northern Ireland (page does not exist)">Northern Ireland</a> to <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a>. Notable composers of classical music from the United Kingdom and the countries that preceded it include <a href="/wiki/William_Byrd" title="William Byrd">William Byrd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Purcell" title="Henry Purcell">Henry Purcell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edward_Elgar" title="Edward Elgar">Sir Edward Elgar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gustav_Holst" title="Gustav Holst">Gustav Holst</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Sullivan" title="Arthur Sullivan">Sir Arthur Sullivan</a> (most famous for working with librettist <a href="/w/index.php?title=W._S._Gilbert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="W. S. Gilbert (page does not exist)">Sir W.S. Gilbert</a>), <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Vaughan_Williams" title="Ralph Vaughan Williams">Ralph Vaughan Williams</a> and <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Britten" title="Benjamin Britten">Benjamin Britten</a>, pioneer of modern British opera. <a href="/wiki/Peter_Maxwell_Davies" title="Peter Maxwell Davies">Sir Peter Maxwell Davies</a> is one of the foremost living composers and current <a href="/wiki/Master_of_the_Queen%27s_Music" title="Master of the Queen's Music">Master of the Queen's Music</a>. The UK is also home to world-renowned symphonic orchestras and choruses such as the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Symphony_Orchestra" title="BBC Symphony Orchestra">BBC Symphony Orchestra</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=London_Symphony_Chorus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="London Symphony Chorus (page does not exist)">London Symphony Chorus</a>. Notable conductors include <a href="/wiki/Simon_Rattle" title="Simon Rattle">Sir Simon Rattle</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Barbirolli" title="John Barbirolli">John Barbirolli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_Sargent" title="Malcolm Sargent">Sir Malcolm Sargent</a>. Some of the notable <a href="/wiki/Film_score" title="Film score">film score</a> composers include <a href="/wiki/John_Barry_(composer)" title="John Barry (composer)">John Barry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clint_Mansell" title="Clint Mansell">Clint Mansell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Oldfield" title="Mike Oldfield">Mike Oldfield</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Powell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Powell (page does not exist)">John Powell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Craig_Armstrong_(composer)" title="Craig Armstrong (composer)">Craig Armstrong</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Arnold" title="David Arnold">David Arnold</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Murphy_(composer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Murphy (composer) (page does not exist)">John Murphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monty_Norman" title="Monty Norman">Monty Norman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harry_Gregson-Williams" title="Harry Gregson-Williams">Harry Gregson-Williams</a>. <a href="/wiki/George_Frideric_Handel" title="George Frideric Handel">George Frideric Handel</a>, although born German, was a <a href="/wiki/Naturalization" title="Naturalization">naturalised</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_nationality_law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British nationality law (page does not exist)">British citizen</a><sup id="cite_ref-Handel_412-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Handel-412">[402]</a></sup> and some of his best works, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Messiah_(Handel)" title="Messiah (Handel)">Messiah</a></i>, were written in the English language.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[403]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Lloyd_Webber" title="Andrew Lloyd Webber">Andrew Lloyd Webber</a> has achieved enormous worldwide commercial success and is a prolific composer of musical theatre, works which have dominated London's <a href="/wiki/West_End_Theatre" title="West End Theatre" class="mw-redirect">West End</a> for a number of years and have travelled to Broadway in New York.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[404]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> have international sales of over one billion units and are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">biggest-selling</a> and most influential band in the history of popular music.<sup id="cite_ref-Beatles_sales_409-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beatles_sales-409">[399]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-McCartney_410-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCartney-410">[400]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Guinness_411-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guinness-411">[401]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[405]</a></sup> Other prominent British contributors to have influenced popular music over the last 50 years include; <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">The Rolling Stones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Led_Zeppelin" title="Led Zeppelin">Led Zeppelin</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pink_Floyd&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pink Floyd (page does not exist)">Pink Floyd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queen_(band)" title="Queen (band)">Queen</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bee_Gees" title="Bee Gees">Bee Gees</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elton_John&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elton John (page does not exist)">Elton John</a>, all of whom have world wide record sales of 200&#160;million or more.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[406]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[407]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[408]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[409]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[410]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[411]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Brit_Awards" title="Brit Awards">Brit Awards</a> are the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Phonographic_Industry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Phonographic Industry (page does not exist)">BPI</a>'s annual music awards, and some of the British recipients of the Outstanding Contribution to Music award include; <a href="/wiki/The_Who" title="The Who">The Who</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Bowie" title="David Bowie">David Bowie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eric_Clapton" title="Eric Clapton">Eric Clapton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rod_Stewart" title="Rod Stewart">Rod Stewart</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Police" title="The Police">The Police</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[412]</a></sup> More recent UK music acts that have had international success include <a href="/wiki/Coldplay" title="Coldplay">Coldplay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radiohead" title="Radiohead">Radiohead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oasis_(band)" title="Oasis (band)">Oasis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spice_Girls" title="Spice Girls">Spice Girls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amy_Winehouse" title="Amy Winehouse">Amy Winehouse</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adele_(singer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adele (singer) (page does not exist)">Adele</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[413]</a></sup>
</p><p>A number of UK cities are known for their music. Acts from <a href="/wiki/Liverpool" title="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> have had more UK chart number one hit singles per capita (54) than any other city worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-Liverpool_vs_Stavanger_424-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Liverpool_vs_Stavanger-424">[414]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>'s contribution to music was recognised in 2008 when it was named a <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNESCO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNESCO (page does not exist)">UNESCO</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Creative_Cities_Network&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Creative Cities Network (page does not exist)">City of Music</a>, one of only three cities in the world to have this honour.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[415]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_art">Visual art</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Turner_selfportrait.jpg" title="File:Turner selfportrait.jpg">File:Turner selfportrait.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/J._M._W._Turner" title="J. M. W. Turner">J. M. W. Turner</a> self-portrait, oil on canvas, c. 1799</div></div></div>
<p>The history of British visual art forms part of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_art_history&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western art history (page does not exist)">western art history</a>. Major British artists include: the <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romantics</a> <a href="/wiki/William_Blake" title="William Blake">William Blake</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Constable" title="John Constable">John Constable</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Palmer" title="Samuel Palmer">Samuel Palmer</a> and <a href="/wiki/J.M.W._Turner" title="J.M.W. Turner" class="mw-redirect">J.M.W. Turner</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Portrait" title="Portrait">portrait</a> painters <a href="/wiki/Joshua_Reynolds" title="Joshua Reynolds">Sir Joshua Reynolds</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lucian_Freud" title="Lucian Freud">Lucian Freud</a>; the landscape artists <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Gainsborough" title="Thomas Gainsborough">Thomas Gainsborough</a> and <a href="/wiki/L._S._Lowry" title="L. S. Lowry">L. S.
