Lowry</a>; the pioneer of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arts_and_Crafts_Movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arts and Crafts Movement (page does not exist)">Arts and Crafts Movement</a> <a href="/wiki/William_Morris" title="William Morris">William Morris</a>; the figurative painter <a href="/wiki/Francis_Bacon" title="Francis Bacon">Francis Bacon</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Pop_artist" title="Pop artist" class="mw-redirect">Pop artists</a> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Blake_(artist)" title="Peter Blake (artist)">Peter Blake</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Hamilton_(artist)" title="Richard Hamilton (artist)">Richard Hamilton</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Hockney" title="David Hockney">David Hockney</a>; the collaborative duo <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gilbert_and_George&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gilbert and George (page does not exist)">Gilbert and George</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Abstract_art" title="Abstract art">abstract</a> artist <a href="/wiki/Howard_Hodgkin" title="Howard Hodgkin">Howard Hodgkin</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Sculpture" title="Sculpture">sculptors</a> <a href="/wiki/Antony_Gormley" title="Antony Gormley">Antony Gormley</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anish_Kapoor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anish Kapoor (page does not exist)">Anish Kapoor</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Henry_Moore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Henry Moore (page does not exist)">Henry Moore</a>. During the late 1980s and 1990s the <a href="/wiki/Saatchi_Gallery" title="Saatchi Gallery">Saatchi Gallery</a> in London helped to bring to public attention a group of multi-genre artists who would become known as the "<a href="/wiki/Young_British_Artists" title="Young British Artists">Young British Artists</a>": <a href="/wiki/Damien_Hirst" title="Damien Hirst">Damien Hirst</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chris_Ofili" title="Chris Ofili">Chris Ofili</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rachel_Whiteread" title="Rachel Whiteread">Rachel Whiteread</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tracey_Emin" title="Tracey Emin">Tracey Emin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Wallinger" title="Mark Wallinger">Mark Wallinger</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Steve_McQueen_(artist)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steve McQueen (artist) (page does not exist)">Steve McQueen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sam_Taylor-Wood" title="Sam Taylor-Wood">Sam Taylor-Wood</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Jake_and_Dinos_Chapman" title="Jake and Dinos Chapman">Chapman Brothers</a> are among the better-known members of this loosely affiliated movement.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Academy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Academy (page does not exist)">Royal Academy</a> in London is a key organisation for the promotion of the visual arts in the United Kingdom. Major schools of art in the UK include: the six-school <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_the_Arts_London&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of the Arts London (page does not exist)">University of the Arts London</a>, which includes the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Saint_Martins_College_of_Art_and_Design&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design (page does not exist)">Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chelsea_College_of_Art_and_Design&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chelsea College of Art and Design (page does not exist)">Chelsea College of Art and Design</a>; <a href="/wiki/Goldsmiths,_University_of_London" title="Goldsmiths, University of London">Goldsmiths, University of London</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Slade_School_of_Fine_Art" title="Slade School of Fine Art">Slade School of Fine Art</a> (part of <a href="/wiki/University_College_London" title="University College London">University College London</a>); the <a href="/wiki/Glasgow_School_of_Art" title="Glasgow School of Art">Glasgow School of Art</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Art" title="Royal College of Art">Royal College of Art</a>; and <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Ruskin_School_of_Drawing_and_Fine_Art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Art (page does not exist)">The Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Art</a> (part of the University of Oxford). The <a href="/wiki/Courtauld_Institute_of_Art" title="Courtauld Institute of Art">Courtauld Institute of Art</a> is a leading centre for the teaching of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of art (page does not exist)">history of art</a>. Important art galleries in the United Kingdom include the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Portrait_Gallery_(London)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Portrait Gallery (London) (page does not exist)">National Portrait Gallery</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tate_Britain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tate Britain (page does not exist)">Tate Britain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tate_Modern" title="Tate Modern">Tate Modern</a> (the most-visited modern art gallery in the world, with around 4.7&#160;million visitors per year).<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[416]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Alfred_Hitchcock_NYWTSm.jpg" title="File:Alfred Hitchcock NYWTSm.jpg">File:Alfred Hitchcock NYWTSm.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a></div></div></div>
<p>The United Kingdom has had a considerable influence on the history of the cinema. The British directors <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a>, whose film <i><a href="/wiki/Vertigo_(film)" title="Vertigo (film)">Vertigo</a></i> is considered by some critics as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best" title="List of films considered the best">best film of all time</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-bbc_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-427">[417]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/David_Lean" title="David Lean">David Lean</a> are among the most critically acclaimed of all-time.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[418]</a></sup> Other important directors including <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Chaplin" title="Charlie Chaplin">Charlie Chaplin</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[419]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Michael_Powell" title="Michael Powell">Michael Powell</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[420]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Carol_Reed" title="Carol Reed">Carol Reed</a><sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[421]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ridley_Scott" title="Ridley Scott">Ridley Scott</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[422]</a></sup> Many British actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including: <a href="/wiki/Julie_Andrews" title="Julie Andrews">Julie Andrews</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[423]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Richard_Burton" title="Richard Burton">Richard Burton</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[424]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Michael_Caine" title="Michael Caine">Michael Caine</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[425]</a></sup> Charlie Chaplin,<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[426]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sean_Connery" title="Sean Connery">Sean Connery</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[427]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vivien_Leigh" title="Vivien Leigh">Vivien Leigh</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[428]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/David_Niven" title="David Niven">David Niven</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[429]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier" title="Laurence Olivier">Laurence Olivier</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[430]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Sellers" title="Peter Sellers">Peter Sellers</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[431]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kate_Winslet" title="Kate Winslet">Kate Winslet</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[432]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis" title="Daniel Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a>, the only person to win an Oscar in the best actor category three times.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[433]</a></sup> Some of the most commercially successful films of all time have been produced in the United Kingdom, including the two <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_highest-grossing_film_series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of highest-grossing film series (page does not exist)">highest-grossing film franchises</a> (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Harry_Potter_(film_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Harry Potter (film series) (page does not exist)">Harry Potter</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Bond_(film_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Bond (film series) (page does not exist)">James Bond</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[434]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ealing_Studios" title="Ealing Studios">Ealing Studios</a> has a claim to being the oldest continuously working film studio in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[435]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of American and European influence. British producers are active in <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_co-productions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International co-productions (page does not exist)">international co-productions</a> and British actors, directors and crew feature regularly in American films. Many successful Hollywood films have been based on British people, <a href="/wiki/British_literature" title="British literature">stories</a> or events, including <i><a href="/wiki/Titanic_(1997_film)" title="Titanic (1997 film)">Titanic</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings_film_trilogy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Lord of the Rings film trilogy (page does not exist)">The Lord of the Rings</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_films&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pirates of the Caribbean films (page does not exist)">Pirates of the Caribbean</a></i>.
</p><p>In 2009, British films grossed around $2&#160;billion worldwide and achieved a market share of around 7% globally and 17% in the United Kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-statistics_446-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-statistics-446">[436]</a></sup> UK box-office takings totalled £944&#160;million in 2009, with around 173&#160;million admissions.<sup id="cite_ref-statistics_446-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-statistics-446">[436]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Film_Institute" title="British Film Institute">British Film Institute</a> has produced a poll ranking of what it considers to be the 100 greatest British films of all time, the <a href="/wiki/BFI_Top_100_British_films" title="BFI Top 100 British films">BFI Top 100 British films</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[437]</a></sup> The annual <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_Film_Awards" title="British Academy Film Awards">British Academy Film Awards</a>, hosted by the <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_of_Film_and_Television_Arts" title="British Academy of Film and Television Arts">British Academy of Film and Television Arts</a>, are the British equivalent of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award (page does not exist)">Oscars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[438]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg" title="File:Bbc broadcasting house front.jpg">File:Bbc broadcasting house front.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Broadcasting_House" title="Broadcasting House">Broadcasting House</a> in London, headquarters of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC (page does not exist)">BBC</a>, the oldest and largest broadcaster in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-MediaNewsline_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MediaNewsline-449">[439]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ProspectMag_450-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ProspectMag-450">[440]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AboutBBC_451-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AboutBBC-451">[441]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The BBC, founded in 1922, is the UK's publicly funded radio, television and Internet broadcasting corporation, and is the oldest and largest broadcaster in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-MediaNewsline_449-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MediaNewsline-449">[439]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ProspectMag_450-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ProspectMag-450">[440]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AboutBBC_451-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AboutBBC-451">[441]</a></sup> It operates numerous television and radio stations in the UK and abroad and its domestic services are funded by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Television_licensing_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Television licensing in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">television licence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_452-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-452">[442]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[443]</a></sup> Other major players in the UK media include <a href="/wiki/ITV_plc" title="ITV plc">ITV plc</a>, which operates 11 of the 15 regional television broadcasters that make up the <a href="/wiki/ITV_(TV_network)" title="ITV (TV network)">ITV Network</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[444]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/News_Corporation" title="News Corporation">News Corporation</a>, which owns a number of national newspapers through <a href="/w/index.php?title=News_International&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="News International (page does not exist)">News International</a> such as the most popular <a href="/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format)" title="Tabloid (newspaper format)">tabloid</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Sun_(United_Kingdom)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Sun (United Kingdom) (page does not exist)">The Sun</a></i> and the longest-established daily "<a href="/wiki/Broadsheet" title="Broadsheet">broadsheet</a>" <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[445]</a></sup> as well as holding a large stake in satellite broadcaster <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Sky_Broadcasting&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Sky Broadcasting (page does not exist)">British Sky Broadcasting</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[446]</a></sup> London dominates the media sector in the UK: national newspapers and television and radio are largely based there, although Manchester is also a significant national media centre. Edinburgh and Glasgow, and Cardiff, are important centres of newspaper and broadcasting production in Scotland and Wales respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[447]</a></sup> The UK publishing sector, including books, directories and databases, journals, magazines and business media, newspapers and news agencies, has a combined turnover of around £20 billion and employs around 167,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458">[448]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, it was estimated that individuals viewed a mean of 3.75 hours of television per day and 2.81 hours of radio. In that year the main BBC <a href="/wiki/Public_service_broadcasting_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Public service broadcasting in the United Kingdom">public service broadcasting</a> channels accounted for an estimated 28.4% of all television viewing; the three main independent channels accounted for 29.5% and the increasingly important other satellite and digital channels for the remaining 42.1%.<sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[449]</a></sup> Sales of newspapers have fallen since the 1970s and in 2009 42% of people reported reading a daily national newspaper.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[450]</a></sup> In 2010 82.5% of the UK population were Internet users, the highest proportion amongst the 20 countries with the largest total number of users in that year.<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">[451]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy">Philosophy</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The United Kingdom is famous for the tradition of 'British Empiricism', a branch of the philosophy of knowledge that states that only knowledge verified by experience is valid, and 'Scottish Philosophy', sometimes referred to as the '<a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_School_of_Common_Sense&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish School of Common Sense (page does not exist)">Scottish School of Common Sense</a>'.<sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">[452]</a></sup> The most famous philosophers of British Empiricism are <a href="/wiki/John_Locke" title="John Locke">John Locke</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Berkeley" title="George Berkeley">George Berkeley</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Hume" title="David Hume">David Hume</a>; while <a href="/wiki/Dugald_Stewart" title="Dugald Stewart">Dugald Stewart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Reid" title="Thomas Reid">Thomas Reid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sir_William_Hamilton,_9th_Baronet" title="Sir William Hamilton, 9th Baronet">William Hamilton</a> were major exponents of the Scottish "common sense" school. Two Britons are also notable for a theory of moral philosophy <a href="/wiki/Utilitarianism" title="Utilitarianism">utilitarianism</a>, first used by <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Bentham" title="Jeremy Bentham">Jeremy Bentham</a> and later by <a href="/wiki/John_Stuart_Mill" title="John Stuart Mill">John Stuart Mill</a> in his short work <i><a href="/wiki/Utilitarianism_(book)" title="Utilitarianism (book)">Utilitarianism</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[453]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[454]</a></sup>
Other eminent philosophers from the UK and the unions and countries that preceded it include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Duns_Scotus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Duns Scotus (page does not exist)">Duns Scotus</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Lilburne" title="John Lilburne">John Lilburne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mary_Wollstonecraft" title="Mary Wollstonecraft">Mary Wollstonecraft</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sir_Francis_Bacon" title="Sir Francis Bacon" class="mw-redirect">Sir Francis Bacon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adam_Smith" title="Adam Smith">Adam Smith</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Hobbes" title="Thomas Hobbes">Thomas Hobbes</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_of_Ockham" title="William of Ockham">William of Ockham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bertrand_Russell" title="Bertrand Russell">Bertrand Russell</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alfred_Jules_Ayer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alfred Jules Ayer (page does not exist)">A.J. "Freddie" Ayer</a>. Foreign-born philosophers who settled in the UK include <a href="/wiki/Isaiah_Berlin" title="Isaiah Berlin">Isaiah Berlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karl_Marx" title="Karl Marx">Karl Marx</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karl_Popper" title="Karl Popper">Karl Popper</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ludwig_Wittgenstein" title="Ludwig Wittgenstein">Ludwig Wittgenstein</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wembley_Stadium,_illuminated.jpg" title="File:Wembley Stadium, illuminated.jpg">File:Wembley Stadium, illuminated.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Wembley_Stadium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wembley Stadium (page does not exist)">Wembley Stadium</a>, London, home of the <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">England national football team</a>, is one of the most expensive stadia ever built.<sup id="cite_ref-Daily_Mail_-_stadium_ready_465-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Daily_Mail_-_stadium_ready-465">[455]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Major sports, including <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">rugby league</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golf&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golf (page does not exist)">golf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">rowing</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cricket&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cricket (page does not exist)">cricket</a>, originated or were substantially developed in the UK and the states that preceded it. With the rules and codes of many modern sports invented and codified in late 19th century <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victorian_Britain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victorian Britain (page does not exist)">Victorian Britain</a>, in 2012, IOC President <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Rogge" title="Jacques Rogge">Jacques Rogge</a> stated; "This great, sports-loving country is widely recognized as the birthplace of modern sport. It was here that the concepts of sportsmanship and fair play were first codified into clear rules and regulations. It was here that sport was included as an educational tool in the school curriculum".<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[456]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[457]</a></sup>
</p><p>In most international competitions, separate teams represent England, Scotland and Wales. Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland usually field a single team representing all of Ireland, with notable exceptions being association football and the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_Games" title="Commonwealth Games">Commonwealth Games</a>. In sporting contexts, the English, Scottish, Welsh and Irish / Northern Irish teams are often referred to collectively as the <a href="/wiki/Home_Nations" title="Home Nations">Home Nations</a>. There are some sports in which a single team represents the whole of United Kingdom, including the Olympics, where the UK is represented by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Britain_at_the_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Britain at the Olympics (page does not exist)">Great Britain team</a>. The <a href="/wiki/1908_Summer_Olympics" title="1908 Summer Olympics">1908</a>, <a href="/wiki/1948_Summer_Olympics" title="1948 Summer Olympics">1948</a> Olympic Games and <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012</a> were held in London, making it the first city to play host for a third time.
</p><p>A 2003 poll found that football is the most popular <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Sport in the United Kingdom">sport in the United Kingdom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468">[458]</a></sup> Each of the Home Nations has its own football association, national team and <a href="/wiki/League_system" title="League system">league system</a>. The English top division, the <a href="/wiki/Premier_League" title="Premier League">Premier League</a>, is the most watched football league in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[459]</a></sup> The first-ever international football match was contested by <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">England</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team" title="Scotland national football team">Scotland</a> on 30 November 1872.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_article_470-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_article-470">[460]</a></sup> England, Scotland, <a href="/wiki/Wales_national_football_team" title="Wales national football team">Wales</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team" title="Northern Ireland national football team">Northern Ireland</a> compete as separate countries in international competitions.<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[461]</a></sup> A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Britain_Olympic_football_team&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Britain Olympic football team (page does not exist)">Great Britain Olympic football team</a> was assembled for the first time to compete in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=London_2012_Olympic_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="London 2012 Olympic Games (page does not exist)">London 2012 Olympic Games</a>. However, the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Football_Association" title="Scottish Football Association">Scottish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Football_Association_of_Wales" title="Football Association of Wales">Welsh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Irish_Football_Association" title="Irish Football Association">Northern Irish</a> football associations declined to participate, fearing that it would undermine their independent status&#160;– a fear confirmed by FIFA president Sepp Blatter.<sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">[462]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium,_Cardiff.jpg" title="File:Inside the Millennium Stadium, Cardiff.jpg">File:Inside the Millennium Stadium, Cardiff.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Stadium" title="Millennium Stadium">Millennium Stadium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a>, opened for the <a href="/wiki/1999_Rugby_World_Cup" title="1999 Rugby World Cup">1999 Rugby World Cup</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cricket&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cricket (page does not exist)">Cricket</a> was invented in England. The <a href="/wiki/England_cricket_team" title="England cricket team">England cricket team</a>, controlled by the <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales_Cricket_Board" title="England and Wales Cricket Board">England and Wales Cricket Board</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473">[463]</a></sup> is the only national team in the UK with <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">Test status</a>. Team members are drawn from the main county sides, and include both English and Welsh players. Cricket is distinct from football and rugby where Wales and England field separate national teams, although Wales had fielded its own team in the past. <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Ireland" title="Sport in Ireland">Irish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cricket_in_Scotland" title="Cricket in Scotland">Scottish</a> players have played for England because neither <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_cricket_team" title="Scotland national cricket team">Scotland</a> nor <a href="/wiki/Ireland_cricket_team" title="Ireland cricket team">Ireland</a> have Test status and have only recently started to play in <a href="/wiki/One_Day_International" title="One Day International">One Day Internationals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[464]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475">[465]</a></sup> Scotland, England (and Wales), and Ireland (including Northern Ireland) have competed at the <a href="/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup" title="Cricket World Cup">Cricket World Cup</a>, with England reaching the finals on three occasions. There is a professional <a href="/wiki/County_Championship" title="County Championship">league championship</a> in which clubs representing 17 English counties and 1 Welsh county compete.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[466]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">Rugby league</a> is a popular sport in some regions of the UK. It originated in Huddersfield and is generally played in <a href="/wiki/Northern_England" title="Northern England">Northern England</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[467]</a></sup> A single 'Great Britain Lions' team had competed in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rugby_League_World_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rugby League World Cup (page does not exist)">Rugby League World Cup</a> and Test match games, but this changed in 2008 when <a href="/wiki/England_national_rugby_league_team" title="England national rugby league team">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_rugby_league_team" title="Scotland national rugby league team">Scotland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ireland_national_rugby_league_team" title="Ireland national rugby league team">Ireland</a> competed as separate nations.<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478">[468]</a></sup> Great Britain is still being retained as the full national team for Ashes tours against Australia, New Zealand and France. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Super_League&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Super League (page does not exist)">Super League</a> is the highest level of professional rugby league in the UK and Europe. It consists of 11 teams from Northern England, 1 from London, 1 from Wales and 1 from France.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a>, England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, France and Italy compete in the <a href="/wiki/Six_Nations_Championship" title="Six Nations Championship">Six Nations Championship</a>; the premier international tournament in the northern hemisphere. <a href="/wiki/Sport_governing_body" title="Sport governing body">Sport governing bodies</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rugby_union_in_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rugby union in England (page does not exist)">England</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rugby_union_in_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rugby union in Scotland (page does not exist)">Scotland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union_in_Wales" title="Rugby union in Wales">Wales</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rugby_union_in_Ireland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rugby union in Ireland (page does not exist)">Ireland</a> organise and regulate the game separately.<sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">[469]</a></sup> If any of the British teams or the Irish team beat the other three in a tournament, then it is awarded the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Crown_(rugby_union)" title="Triple Crown (rugby union)">Triple Crown</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480">[470]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Centre_Court_roof.jpg" title="File:Centre Court roof.jpg">File:Centre Court roof.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a> Championships, a <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> tennis tournament, is held in <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon,_London" title="Wimbledon, London">Wimbledon, London</a> every June or July.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Thoroughbred_horse_race&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thoroughbred horse race (page does not exist)">Thoroughbred racing</a>, which originated under <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II of England</a> as the "sport of kings", is popular throughout the UK with world-famous races including the <a href="/wiki/Grand_National" title="Grand National">Grand National</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Epsom_Derby" title="Epsom Derby">Epsom Derby</a>, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Ascot" title="Royal Ascot" class="mw-redirect">Royal Ascot</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheltenham_National_Hunt_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheltenham National Hunt Festival (page does not exist)">Cheltenham National Hunt Festival</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Cheltenham_Gold_Cup" title="Cheltenham Gold Cup">Cheltenham Gold Cup</a>). The UK has proved successful in the international sporting arena in <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">rowing</a>.
</p><p>The UK is closely associated with <a href="/wiki/Motorsport" title="Motorsport">motorsport</a>. Many teams and drivers in <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> (F1) are based in the UK, and drivers from Britain have won more world titles than any other country. The UK hosted the very first F1 Grand Prix in 1950 at <a href="/wiki/Silverstone_Circuit" title="Silverstone Circuit">Silverstone</a>, the current location of the <a href="/wiki/British_Grand_Prix" title="British Grand Prix">British Grand Prix</a> held each year in July. The country also hosts legs of the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Prix_motorcycle_racing" title="Grand Prix motorcycle racing">Grand Prix motorcycle racing</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Rally_Championship" title="World Rally Championship">World Rally Championship</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=FIA_World_Endurance_Championship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FIA World Endurance Championship (page does not exist)">FIA World Endurance Championship</a>. The premier national auto racing event is the <a href="/wiki/British_Touring_Car_Championship" title="British Touring Car Championship">British Touring Car Championship</a> (BTCC). Motorcycle road racing has a long tradition with races such as the <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man_TT" title="Isle of Man TT">Isle of Man TT</a> and the <a href="/wiki/North_West_200" title="North West 200">North West 200</a>.
</p><p>Golf is the sixth most popular sport, by participation, in the UK. Although <a href="/wiki/The_Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews" title="The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews">The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews</a> in Scotland is the sport's home course,<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481">[471]</a></sup> the world's oldest golf course is actually Musselburgh Links' Old Golf Course.<sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482">[472]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Snooker" title="Snooker">Snooker</a> is one of the UK's popular sporting exports, with the world championships held annually in <a href="/wiki/Sheffield" title="Sheffield">Sheffield</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483">[473]</a></sup> The modern game of <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">lawn tennis</a> first originated in the city of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Birmingham&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birmingham (page does not exist)">Birmingham</a> between 1859 and 1865.<sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484">[474]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">The Championships, Wimbledon</a> are international tennis events held in <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon,_London" title="Wimbledon, London">Wimbledon</a> in south London every summer and are regarded as the most prestigious event of the global tennis calendar. In Northern Ireland <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_football" title="Gaelic football">Gaelic football</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hurling" title="Hurling">hurling</a> are popular team sports, both in terms of participation and spectating, and Irish expatriates in the UK and the US also play them.<sup id="cite_ref-CJSHurl_485-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CJSHurl-485">[475]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shinty" title="Shinty">Shinty</a> (or <i>camanachd</i>) is popular in the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">Scottish Highlands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-486" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-486">[476]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbols">Symbols</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Britannia-Statue.jpg" title="File:Britannia-Statue.jpg">File:Britannia-Statue.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Statue of <a href="/wiki/Britannia" title="Britannia">Britannia</a> in <a href="/wiki/Plymouth" title="Plymouth">Plymouth</a>. Britannia is a <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">national personification</a> of the UK.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Flag of the United Kingdom">flag of the United Kingdom</a> is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Union_Flag&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Union Flag (page does not exist)">Union Flag</a> (also referred to as the Union Jack). It was created in 1606 by the superimposition of the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_England" title="Flag of England">Flag of England</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Scotland" title="Flag of Scotland">Flag of Scotland</a> and updated in 1801 with the addition of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Patrick%27s_Flag&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saint Patrick's Flag (page does not exist)">Saint Patrick's Flag</a>. Wales is not represented in the Union Flag, as Wales had been conquered and annexed to England prior to the formation of the United Kingdom. The possibility of redesigning the Union Flag to include representation of Wales has not been completely ruled out.<sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487">[477]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_anthem" title="National anthem">national anthem</a> of the United Kingdom is "<a href="/wiki/God_Save_the_Queen" title="God Save the Queen">God Save the King</a>", with "King" replaced with "Queen" in the lyrics whenever the monarch is a woman.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Britannia" title="Britannia">Britannia</a> is a <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">national personification</a> of the United Kingdom, originating from <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">Roman Britain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488">[478]</a></sup> Britannia is symbolised as a young woman with brown or golden hair, wearing a <a href="/wiki/Corinthian_helmet" title="Corinthian helmet">Corinthian helmet</a> and white robes. She holds <a href="/wiki/Poseidon" title="Poseidon">Poseidon</a>'s three-pronged trident and a shield, bearing the Union Flag. Sometimes she is depicted as riding on the back of a lion. Since the height of the British Empire in the late 19th century, Britannia has often been associated with British maritime dominance, as in the patriotic song "<a href="/wiki/Rule,_Britannia!" title="Rule, Britannia!">Rule, Britannia!</a>". Up until 2008, the lion symbol was depicted behind Britannia on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fifty_pence_(British_decimal_coin)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fifty pence (British decimal coin) (page does not exist)">British fifty pence coin</a> and on the back of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ten_pence_(British_decimal_coin)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ten pence (British decimal coin) (page does not exist)">British ten pence coin</a>. It is also used as a symbol on the non-ceremonial flag of the British Army. The <a href="/wiki/Bulldog" title="Bulldog">bulldog</a> is sometimes used as a symbol of the United Kingdom and has been associated with Winston Churchill's defiance of Nazi Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-489" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489">[479]</a></sup>
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
